{{Infobox building | name = 425 Market Street | alternate_names = 1 Metropolitan Life Plaza
1 Metro Plaza | image = 425 Market Street, San Francisco.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | location = 425 [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market Street]]
[[San Francisco]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.7911|-122.3981|region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | completion_date = 1973 | architect = [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] | owner = | cost = | floor_area = {{convert|905000|sqft|abbr=on}} | top_floor = | floor_count = 38 | references = {{emporis|118729}}{{Skyscraperpage|786}}{{Structurae|s0021845}} | building_type = Commercial offices | roof = {{convert|160|m|abbr=on}} | elevator_count = 21 | structural_engineer= | main_contractor = | pushpin_map = United States San Francisco Central#California | developer = | management = Cushman & Wakefield }} '''425 Market Street''' is an [[office]] [[skyscraper]] located on the corner of [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market]] and Fremont Streets in the [[Financial District (San Francisco)|financial district]] of [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. The {{convert|160|m|abbr=on}}, 38 [[Storey|floor]] office tower was completed in 1973. It was built by the [[Metropolitan Life]] Insurance Company as their "Pacific Coast Headquarters" and was called "1 Metropolitan Plaza". It was built as a modern replacement for their older headquarters on Nob Hill at 600 [[Stockton Street (San Francisco)|Stockton Street]] (now remodeled as the Ritz-Carlton Hotel). It was among the first buildings in San Francisco to have a high-speed transport system (a glorified [[dumb waiter]]) for computer data cards, files and inner-office mail, at the time a state-of-the-art system.{{Citation needed|date = February 2015}} Its largest tenant today{{When|date=February 2015}} is [[law firm]] [[Morrison & Foerster LLP]], one of the original tenants when the building first opened.{{Citation needed|date = February 2015}} The building is partially owned by the [[Government Pension Fund of Norway]], who according to their 2015 report{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbim.no/en/the-fund/holdings/|title=Holdings|website=www.nbim.no|access-date=2016-06-12}} owns 47.5%. ==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} * [[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco|San Francisco's tallest buildings]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.425marketst.com/ 425 Market Street official website] * [http://425marketstreet.info/toc.cfm 425 Market Street Tenant Handbook] {{Buildings in San Francisco|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in San Francisco]] [[Category:Market Street (San Francisco)]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1973]] [[Category:Financial District, San Francisco]] [[Category:Skidmore, Owings & Merrill buildings]] [[Category:Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design gold certified buildings]]

[[cross-platform interchange]] | tracks = 4 | structure = Underground | code = 009 | passengers = 11,300,097{{NYCS const|riderref}} | pass_year = 2017 | pass_percent = 17.5 | rank = 27 | open_date = {{start date and age|1919|July|10|p=y}}{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1919/07/10/archives/broadway-end-of-subway-opened-first-passenger-train-sent-at.html |title=Broadway End of Subway Opened |date=July 10, 1919 |p=36}} | accessible = mp | acc_note = | cross_platform = yes | next_north = {{NYCS next | type=63rd | station=Lexington Avenue–63rd Street | line=63rd Street Lines | service=63rd BMT northbound}}
{{NYCS next | station=Fifth Avenue–59th Street | line=BMT Broadway Line | service=Broadway 60th}} | next_south = {{NYCS next | type=local | line=BMT Broadway Line | station=49th Street | service=Broadway north local}}
{{NYCS next | type=express | line=BMT Broadway Line | station=Times Square–42nd Street | service=Broadway north express}} | legend = {{NYCS infobox legend|allexceptnights}}{{NYCS infobox legend|alltimes}}{{NYCS infobox legend|weekdaysonly}}{{NYCS infobox legend|limitedrush}}{{NYCS infobox legend|limitedrushpeak}} }} '''57th Street–Seventh Avenue''' is an express [[metro station|station]] on the [[BMT Broadway Line]] of the [[New York City Subway]]. Located in [[Midtown Manhattan]] at the intersection of [[57th Street (Manhattan)|57th Street]] and [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh Avenue]], it is served by the '''[[N (New York City Subway service)|N]]''' and '''[[Q (New York City Subway service)|Q]]''' trains at all times, the '''[[R (New York City Subway service)|R]]''' train at all times except late nights, and the '''[[W (New York City Subway service)|W]]''' train on weekdays. On the [[New York City Subway map|subway map]] and on announcements, the station is called '''57th Street–Seventh Avenue''',{{NYCS const|map}} but is also sometimes called '''Midtown–57th Street'''. It is directly adjacent to [[Carnegie Hall]]. == Station layout == {|table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=3 |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''G''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Street level |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=600 valign=top|Exit/Entrance |- |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''M''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Mezzanine |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=600 valign=top|Fare control, station agent
{{NYCS Platform Layout access}} |- |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=50 rowspan=6 valign=top|'''P
Platform level''' |style="border-bottom:solid 0px gray;border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100|'''Southbound local''' |style="border-bottom:solid 0px gray;border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=600|← {{rint|newyork|N}} toward [[Coney Island–Stillwell Avenue (New York City Subway)|Coney Island–Stillwell Avenue]] ([[49th Street (BMT Broadway Line)|49th Street]])

→ {{rint|newyork|R}} toward [[Forest Hills–71st Avenue (IND Queens Boulevard Line)|Forest Hills–71st Avenue]] (Fifth Avenue–59th Street) → |} {{Stack|float=right| {{Routemap |title=Track layout |title-bg=#{{NYCS color|Broadway}} |style=margin-left:10px;margin-top:10px;float:right; |legend =track |map= numN330 uvSTR!~MFADEg ~~ ~~ ~~ to [[Lexington Avenue–63rd Street (63rd Street Lines)|Lexington Av–63 St]] uexdENDEa\d\uvSTRfg\d\uexdENDEa ~~ ~~ ~~ Local trackways end uexvSTR-\uvSTR\uexv-STR uexdSTR\udSTR!~dMFADEg\uvSTR\udSTR!~dMFADEg\uexdSTR ~~ ~~ ~~ to [[Fifth Avenue–59th Street (BMT Broadway Line)|5 Av–59 St]] uexdSTR\udSTRf\uvSTR\udSTRg\uexdSTR uxdSHI2g+l\udSHI2lr\udSHI2g+r\udSHI2g+l\udSHI2lr\uxdSHI2g+r ~~ ~~ ~~ Local trackways begin udSTR\dBS\uvSTR\dBS\udSTR udSTR\dBS\uvSTR\dBS\udSTR udSTR\dBS\uvSTR\dBS\udSTR udSTR\dBS\uvSTR\dBS\udSTR uvSHI2l-\uvSTR\uv-SHI2r udSTR\uvÜST\udSTR uvÜST\uvÜST uvSTRf\uvSTRg udSTR!~dMFADEf\uvSTR\udSTR!~dMFADEf ~~ ~~ ~~ to [[49th Street (BMT Broadway Line)|49 St]] uvSTR!~MFADEf ~~ ~~ ~~ to [[Times Square–42nd Street (BMT Broadway Line)|42 St]] }} }} When this station opened on July 10, 1919,{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AINOAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA130&dq=18th+avenue+culver+line&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi7pf-1k87PAhUBXT4KHdbZCbwQ6AEIJjAC#v=onepage&q=18th%20avenue%20culver%20line&f=false|title=Legislative Documents|date=January 1, 1920|publisher=J.B. Lyon Company|language=en}} the BMT Broadway Line had ended north of this station as six trackways, of which only two tracks (local tracks) continued to the [[60th Street Tunnel]] to Queens. The other four trackways, both the express tracks and the outermost trackways (both of the outermost trackways are ramps which have never been used) curve slightly west before ending, which were a provision for the line to run to Upper Manhattan via Central Park West.http://www.nycsubway.org/wiki/New_Subways:_Proposed_Additions_to_Rapid_Transit_System..._(1922) "Section on Broadway Subway Expansion" With four tracks and two [[island platform]]s, this station is the northernmost express station on the BMT Broadway Line. Much of the BMT system is [[New York City Subway chaining|chained]] from the zero point here. The '''N''', '''R''', and '''W''' trains use the local tracks, which continue north under 59th and 60th Streets to [[Queens]], while '''Q''' trains, limited weekday rush hour '''N''' trains and one weekday a.m. rush hour '''R''' train use the center express tracks to continue north along the [[BMT 63rd Street Line]] to [[Lexington Avenue–63rd Street (BMT 63rd Street Line)|Lexington Avenue–63rd Street]] and the [[Second Avenue Subway]]. Before the BMT 63rd Street Line was built in 1989, the express tracks continued as layup spurs north of the station (although construction of the 63rd Street line from 1971 to 1978 continued the section between this station and Lexington Avenue–63rd Street station). The express tracks ran for about 400 feet. North of the station, the local tracks continue into the 60th Street Tunnel to Queens, while the express tracks continue to 63rd Street, with switches to the 60th Street tunnel. South of the station, there are also crossovers between the two express tracks, between both northbound tracks, and between both southbound tracks.{{NYCS const|trackref|nycs|3=http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/caption.pl?/img/trackmap/detail-47-63.png}} This station underwent an overhaul in the late 1970s, which included fixing the station's structure and replacing the original wall tiles, old signs, and incandescent lighting with 1970s modern-look wall tile band and tablet mosaics, signs and fluorescent lights. Staircases and platform edges were also repaired.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} === Elevators === In 1992–1993, the station received a major overhaul with state-of-the-art repairs as well as upgrading the station for [[ADA compliance]]. The original late 1910s tiling was restored, repairs were made to the staircases, new tiling on the floors, upgrades to the station's lights and public address system, installation of ADA safety treads along the platform edge, new signs, and new trackbeds in both directions. Accessibility to the mezzanine was further increased by the addition of a usable elevator on the southwest corner of 57th Street. While elevators have yet to be installed for platform access, it allows disabled access to the fare booth and [[MetroCard (New York City)|MetroCard]] vending machines. The MTA intends to provide ADA access to the platforms as part of the 2010–2014 Capital Plan.{{cite web|url=http://theweeklynabe.com/2013/06/13/mta-key-station-plan-subway-accessibility/|title=The MTA’s Key Station Plan for subway accessibility - The Weekly Nabe|last=|first=|date=June 13, 2013|work=The Weekly Nabe|access-date=February 16, 2018}} Elevators to the platforms have been under design for several years, with the MTA originally planning to award contracts in November 2013,{{Cite web|url=http://web.mta.info/mta/news/books/pdf/180220_1000_Transit.pdf|title=Transit and Bus Committee Meeting February 2018|last=|first=|date=February 20, 2018|website=|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|access-date=February 18, 2018|page=326}} but the design process was delayed several years due to preexisting utilities blocking the way of the proposed elevator access.{{cite web|title=Capital Program Oversight Committee Meeting|url=http://web.mta.info/mta/news/books/pdf/170724_1345_CPOC.pdf|website=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|mta.info]]|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|accessdate=August 31, 2017|date=July 24, 2017|page=84}} Other issues included [[asbestos]] abatement, the lack of available space underground for the expansion of the mezzanine, and the need to negotiate with another developer to install elevators. The MTA started working on a revised design in September 2015. The construction award, and the beginning of construction was finally awarded in December 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://web.mta.info/capitaldashboard/allframenew_head.html?PROJNUM=t6041311&PLTYPE=1|title=T6041311 ADA Accessibility at 57 St Station on the Broadway Line - Phase 2|last=|first=|date=|website=web.mta.info|publisher=Metropolitan Transportation Authority|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 3, 2017}} Ultimately, the location of the platform elevators was moved to the southern end of the station, near 55th Street, necessitating the installation of a new street-to-mezzanine elevator at 55th Street.{{Cite news|url=http://www.fox5ny.com/news/midtown-shops-subway-elevator-construction|title=Midtown shops worry about subway elevator construction|last=Schmidt|first=Linda|date=April 26, 2018|work=WNYW|access-date=2018-05-01|language=en-US}} Substantial completion is projected for February 2021.{{Cite web|url=http://web.mta.info/mta/news/books/pdf/181113_1400_CPOC.pdf|title=Capital Program Oversight Committee Meeting November 2018|date=November 13, 2018|accessdate=November 10, 2018|page=90|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]}} ===Exits=== * Stair to NW corner of 7th Avenue and 57th Street{{cite web|title=MTA Neighborhood Maps: Midtown West|url=http://web.mta.info/maps/neighborhoods/mn/M10_midtown_west_2015.pdf|website=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|mta.info]]|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|accessdate=December 11, 2015|date=2015}} * Stair to NE corner of 7th Avenue and 57th Street * Stair and elevator to SW corner of 7th Avenue and 57th Street * Stair to SE corner of 7th Avenue and 57th Street * Stair to NW corner of 7th Avenue and 55th Street * Stair to NE corner of 7th Avenue and 55th Street * Stair to SW corner of 7th Avenue and 55th Street * Stair to SE corner of 7th Avenue and 55th Street {{-|left}} ==Proposed extension== [[File:BMT 55th St 7 Av NW stair jeh.jpg|thumb|220px|55th Street stairs]] [[File:57th Street BMT 002.JPG|thumb|220px|57 Mosaic]] North of this station are tunnel stub headings running straight from the local tracks{{Citation|last=BMT7thAvenueExpress|title=RFW of The Brooklyn Bound R Part 2: Lexington Avenue to 14th Street Union Square|date=October 17, 2009|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e6dFkV2n3-Y&feature=related|accessdate=February 16, 2018}} ''A trackway is visible towards the right at the 2:51 mark into this video, just before the train enters the 57th Street station.'' for a proposed line under Central Park West or Morningside Avenue, that would have terminated at 145th Street or 155th Street. When the BRT / BMT was building the Broadway line as part of the Dual Contracts, the company also wanted to be awarded the Central Park West / Eighth Avenue route, which was on the planning boards at that time. The company figured that if they built ramps from the Broadway line that could naturally be extended to an Eighth Avenue line, they would get a toehold on being awarded that line, rather than lose out to the IRT, the only other subway operator when the Dual Contracts were built.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XEA8AQAAMAAJ|title=Documents of the Senate of the State of New York|last=Senate|first=New York (State) Legislature|date=January 1, 1916|publisher=E. Croswell|language=en}} The BMT / BRT never built that line for various reasons including the bankruptcy of the company after the [[Malbone Street Wreck]] and Mayor Hylan's plan to include the Eighth Avenue / CPW route in the [[Independent Subway System|IND]] system. The ramps were built but never used for revenue service. They were eventually used for storage until the tracks were disconnected. The disused trackways for the proposed line ramp up and run for about 500 feet. The ramp on the northbound side has a Maintenance-of-Way shed built on it,{{Citation|last=BMT7thAvenueExpress|title=RFW of The Queens Bound R Part 6: 23rd Street to Lexington Avenue|date=August 31, 2009|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sToFk6_5Eo&feature=related|accessdate=February 16, 2018}} ''The shed is visible to the right at the 5:15 mark in the video, as the train leaves the 57th Street station.'' and the trackway on the southbound side also has a storage shed sitting in it, just north of where the local tracks come in, but this shed is few hundred feet north of the shed on the opposite trackway of the other side of the tunnel. Some of the actual track on the trackways remain, but are covered by many years of dirt. They can be seen from passing trains. The never-used trackways curve slightly west before ending.{{Cite news|url=http://ltvsquad.com/2005/06/19/the-bmt-provision/|title=The BMT Provision|last=Anastasio|first=Joe|date=June 19, 2005|work=LTV Squad|access-date=February 16, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} {{clear}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{commons category|57th Street {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Adam Crozier | image = Adam Crozier at Nations & Regions Media Conference.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Adam Crozier speaking at the Nations & Regions Media Conference in 2012 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1964|01|26}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Isle of Bute]], [[Scotland]], United Kingdom}} | nationality = [[British people|British]] | citizenship = United Kingdom | education = [[Graeme High School]] | alma_mater = [[Heriot-Watt University]] | occupation = Businessman | years_active = 1984–present | employer = ITV | home_town = Isle of Bute, Scotland | salary = [[Pound sterling|£]]1.4 million (est.){{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/jan/31/itv-chief-potential-14bn-bonuses | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Katie | last=Allen | title=ITV could give Adam Crozier £14m pay and bonus package | date=31 January 2010}} | title = {{nowrap|CEO of [[Saatchi and Saatchi]](1995–99)
CEO of [[The Football Association|The FA]] (2000–02)
CEO of [[Royal Mail|Royal Mail Holdings plc]] (2003–10)
Non-executive director of
[[Camelot Group|Camelot Group plc]] (2007–10)
CEO of [[ITV plc]] (2010–17)}} | predecessor = [[Michael Grade]] | successor = [[Carolyn McCall]] | spouse = Annette | children = 2 }} '''Adam Alexander Crozier''' (born 26 January 1964) is a Scottish businessman, and was former chief executive officer of media company [[ITV plc]],{{cite web |url= http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=20989502&ticker=ITV:LN&previousCapId=679529&previousTitle=DAILY%20MAIL%26GENERAL%20TST-A%20NV |title=Adam Crozier: Executive Profile & Biography – Businessweek|work=investing.businessweek.com|accessdate=30 October 2012}} operator of the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] television network covering most of the United Kingdom. After a career at [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] culminating with the post of joint chief executive 1995, he came to wide public prominence as the new chief executive of [[The Football Association]] in 2000 at the age of 35, before in 2003 becoming the chief executive of the [[Royal Mail Group]], the United Kingdom's mail delivery service, where he oversaw a controversial modernisation and redundancy programme. In January 2010 he was announced as the new chief executive of ITV plc, where he arrived on 26 April 2010. Crozier announced he was leaving this post in June 2017.{{cite news|last=Kollewe|first=Julia|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/may/03/itv-chief-executive-adam-crozier-steps-down|title=ITV chief executive Adam Crozier steps down after seven years|work=The Guardian|date=3 May 2017|accessdate=3 May 2017}} ==Early life and education== Crozier was born and raised on the [[Isle of Bute]] on the west coast of Scotland in 1964.[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/may/11/postalservice Sharp suit with an iron hand in a woolly glove] ''Guardian'', 11 May 2007]{{cite web | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-77957488.html | title=Rothesay (Town of the Week) | work=[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]] | date=12 November 2000 | accessdate=10 December 2006}} His father was a manager for [[John Crichton-Stuart, 6th Marquess of Bute|Lord Bute]], and his mother was secretary to the managing director of ''[[The Scotsman]]''. Crozier went to a school in [[Ayr]], before moving to [[Graeme High School]], a comprehensive school in [[Falkirk]]. He graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree (BA) in business organisation from [[Edinburgh]]'s [[Heriot-Watt University]]. While at school, Crozier had trials with both [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] and [[Stirling Albion F.C.|Stirling Albion]] football clubs. Crozier received an Honorary Doctorate from [[Heriot-Watt University]] in 2005.{{Cite web|url=http://www1.hw.ac.uk/annual-review/2005/people-lynn2.html |title=Heriot-Watt University Edinburgh & Scottish Borders: Annual Review 2004 |website=www1.hw.ac.uk |access-date=2016-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160413072617/http://www1.hw.ac.uk/annual-review/2005/people-lynn2.html |archivedate=13 April 2016 }} ==Career== ===Early career=== Crozier joined [[Pedigree Petfoods]] as a graduate trainee in 1984. In 1986, he moved to the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' to work in media sales. ===Saatchi & Saatchi=== From 1988 to 1999 Crozier worked for advertising agency [[Saatchi and Saatchi]], becoming media director in 1990, and then being appointed as joint chief executive from 1995 alongside [[Tamara Ingram]]. This occurred in the wake of the departure of the founding Saatchi brothers to form [[M&C Saatchi]]. ===Football Association=== Crozier came to public attention as the surprise appointment to the role of chief executive of [[The Football Association]], the governing body of [[Football in England|England's national game, football]], aged just 35 and having had no experience of business in football.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3115098.stm | title=Profile: Adam Crozier | publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=17 September 2003 | accessdate=28 January 2010}} He replaced [[Graham Kelly (football)|Graham Kelly]]. In his short tenure from 2000 to 2002, the FA relocated headquarters from [[Lancaster Gate]] to [[Soho Square]], appointed the first ever foreign [[England national football team|England national team]] manager, Swede [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]], and became a more commercial organisation, maximising its revenues. He also reduced the average age of the FA's staff from 55 to 32, progressed the [[Wembley Stadium]] redevelopment, and reduced the FA's ruling body from a 91-member FA Board to a committee of 12. His moves were not without criticism, with complaints from some about lack of consultation and of acting beyond his powers. He was replaced by [[Mark Palios]]. While at the FA, Crozier reportedly identified some members of the England national team as the [[Golden Generation]]. It was a term later criticised towards the end of the decade by some England players as having been undeserved, and of causing undue expectations and pressure due to the fact they had at the time, and in years since, failed to win major tournaments.{{cite news | title = World Cup 2010: Gary Neville at odds with England's 'golden generation' tag | publisher = Telegraph Media Group | work = Daily Telegraph | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup-2010/teams/england/7824952/World-Cup-2010-Gary-Neville-at-odds-with-Englands-golden-generation-tag.html | date = 13 June 2010 | accessdate = 10 August 2013 }} {{cite news | title = 'Golden generation' tag annoys Lampard | publisher = The Independent | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/golden-generation-tag-annoys-lampard-1801824.html | date = 13 October 2009 | author = Mark Fleming | accessdate = 2 July 2010 | location=London}} ===Royal Mail=== Crozier became the chief executive of the [[Royal Mail|Royal Mail Group]] in February 2003. {{cite news | title = BBC NEWS – Business – Royal Mail Delivers Record Profit | publisher = [[BBC News]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4553933.stm | date = 17 May 2005 | accessdate = 23 May 2008}} Entering the post, Crozier described his remit as the "biggest corporate turnaround programme in the UK". Crozier initiated a programme of modernisation and reform, to deal with changes in the service brought about by reforms beginning with the [[Postal Services Act 2000]]. In Crozier's first three years, the Royal Mail division produced record annual profits of £537m in May 2005, making £2m a day in profits, up from £1.5m a day losses before he joined. The Group overall had been transformed from recording losses of £1.1bn at the start of the turnaround plan in 2002 into a profit of £355m in 2005. Royal Mail chairman [[Allan Leighton]] said it was a "fantastic turnaround" but also that there was still "a huge amount to do". The newly formed mail regulator [[Postwatch]] were however critical that it had failed to achieve 11 of its 15 licence targets during the previous financial year. As the postal service was opened up to competition in early 2006, Royal Mail recorded losses of £10m in 2006 and £279m in 2007. His reforms included highly controversial large scale post office closures in the thousands, layoffs of Royal Mail staff, changes in working practices, and the ending of the second daily delivery and moving the first daily delivery to later in the day.. {{cite news | title = BBC NEWS – Business – Mail Boss gets £3m in Pay Packet | publisher = [[BBC News]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7417634.stm | date = 23 May 2008 | accessdate = 23 May 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080526023453/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7417634.stm| archivedate= 26 May 2008 | deadurl= no}} [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/royal-mail/6481170/Royal-Mail-strikes-Adam-Crozier-second-highest-paid-public-sector-boss-on-1m.html Royal Mail strikes: Adam Crozier second highest paid public sector boss on £1m] The Daily Telegraph, 2 November 2009 {{cite news | title = Royal Mail rewarding Adam Crozier's 'failure'- Telegraph | publisher = [[Daily Telegraph]] | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/majornews/1567988/Royal-Mail-rewarding-Adam-Crozier's-'failure'.html | date = 19 April 2008 | author = Richard Alleyne and Gordon Rayner | accessdate = 23 May 2008 | location=London}} While at the Royal Mail, Crozier's salary, one of the largest in the country for the head of a publicly owned body, was criticised in light of the changes being made to the Royal Mail workforce. Ongoing reforms eventually led to large scale industrial disputes and strike action in both [[2007 Royal Mail industrial disputes|2007]] and [[2009 Royal Mail industrial disputes|2009 onwards]]. ===ITV plc.=== On 28 January 2010, it was announced Crozier would be leaving the Royal Mail later in 2010 to become the next permanent chief executive of media group [[ITV plc]].[http://www.news.royalmailgroup.com/news/article.asp?id=2663&brand=royal_mail_group Adam Crozier to leave Royal Mail later this year to join ITV] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715205535/http://www.news.royalmailgroup.com/news/article.asp?id=2663&brand=royal_mail_group |date=15 July 2011 }} Royal Mail Group, 28 January 2010 {{cite news | title = ITV appoints Adam Crozier as new boss | publisher = [[BBC News]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8485170.stm | date = 28 January 2010 | accessdate = 28 January 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100129053915/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8485170.stm| archivedate= 29 January 2010 | deadurl= no}} ITV plc., is one of three partners within ITV Network Limited, the not for profit organisation which runs the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] television network, the United Kingdom's first commercial network effectively created under the [[Television Act 1954]]. Crozier was replacing [[Michael Grade]], who announced his intention to leave in April 2009. Crozier was given the task of increasing ITV's advertising revenues which had fallen with the proliferation of new channels in the [[Television in the United Kingdom|British television]] market. On announcing the appointment, ITV chairman [[Archie Norman (businessman)|Archie Norman]] said of Crozier that he is a "very strong leader with a great track record in delivering transformational change". ===Other roles=== Crozier is also a board member of [[Camelot Group]], the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]] operator, and the [[Debenhams]] retail chain.{{cite web|url=http://www.royalmailgroup.com/portal/rmg/content1;jsessionid=DQMRGET2JBAQYFB2IGVERWQUHRA0WQ2K?catId=23200554&mediaId=23200558 |title=Profile: Adam Crozier |publisher=[[Royal Mail]] |accessdate=28 January 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He is also member of the President's Committee of the [[Confederation of British Industry]] (CBI). ==Personal life== Crozier is married to Annette, whom he met while working for [[Saatchi & Saatchi|Saatchi and Saatchi]], and has two children. Despite having taken on high-profile jobs involving pressing through major upheavals, he is described as "softly spoken" and has previously said of the spotlight, "I hate it, absolutely hate it. The bizarre thing about the last three jobs I've done is that I don't like [the public profile] at all. I will go to enormous lengths not to do public things – because it is just not me." ==References== {{reflist}} {{The Football Association}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crozier, Adam}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Alumni of Heriot-Watt University]] [[Category:Chief executives of the Football Association]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Royal Mail]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:Scottish chief executives]] [[Category:Scottish television executives]] [[Category:People from the Isle of Bute]] [[Category:People educated at Graeme High School]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Shafizadeh
علی شفیعی زاده | image = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Iran]] | occupation = Businessman, Owner and Chairman of [[Esteghlal Ahvaz F.C.]] | spouse = | citizenship = [[Iran]] | ethnicity = }} '''Ali Shafizadeh''' ({{lang-fa|علی شفیعی زاده}}) is an [[Iran]]ian businessman. ==Business career== ===Esteghlal Ahvaz=== He is the owner of [[Iran's Premier Football League]] club [[Esteghlal Ahvaz F.C.]] who he bought in 2002. Over the years he has bought numerous players for substantial fees, including [[Adriano Alves]], [[Abdul-Wahab Abu Al-Hail]] and [[Saša Ilić (born 1970)|Saša Ilić]], and coaches such as [[Croats|Croatian]] [[Luka Bonačić]] and [[Serbs|Serbian]] [[Srđan Gemaljević]]. In 2004 Shafizadeh put a $5 million unsuccessful bid to bring [[Brazil]]ian superstar [[Rivaldo]] to the [[Takhti Stadium (Ahvaz)|Takhti Stadium.]].{{cite web |url=http://www.persianleague.com/news/morenews.cfm?news=1674 |title=Blues of Ahvaz propose a five million dollar deal to Rivaldo! |publisher=persianleague.com |accessdate=2007-06-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927191920/http://www.persianleague.com/news/morenews.cfm?news=1674 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |deadurl=no |df= }} Shafizadeh sparked much controversy on February 15, 2007 when he announced [[Esteghlal Ahvaz F.C.]] were to withdraw from [[Iran's Premier Football League|IPL]]. However, the team appeared two days later in a league match against [[Persepolis F.C.]] which ended 1-0 to [[Esteghlal Ahvaz F.C.|Esteghlal Ahvaz]], dismissing these claims and led people to believe it was all tactical games before one of the biggest games of their season versus Persepolis.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/Articolo.aspx?ContenutoId=234176|title=Iran: Esteghlal Threaten To Quit League|publisher=goal.com|accessdate=2007-06-05}} ===Esteghlal Kish=== Shafizadeh also owned the [[Azadegan League]] club [[Esteghlal Kish F.C.]], which is based in [[Kish Island]] in the [[Persian Gulf]], from 2002 to 2006, until it was bought by [[Shahrdari Bandar Abbas F.C.]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irankicks.com/newscast/data/fullstory/EEVVlFZkFExtKHgeOP.php |title=Hottest transfer market|publisher=irankicks.com|accessdate=2007-06-05}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-bus}} {{succession box | title=[[Esteghlal Ahvaz F.C.|Esteghlal Ahvaz]] chairman | before= [[Nasrollah Heibodi]] | after=''Incumbent'' | years=2002–}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shafizadeh, Ali}} [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:Iranian football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Iranian sports executives and administrators]] {{Iran-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Andrei Mocioni de Foen | image = Mocsonyi András, 1865.jpg | imagesize = 230px | caption = Mocioni as [[Diet of Hungary]] deputy, 1865 | order = Supreme commissioner for the [[Banat]] | term_start = 1849 | term_end = 1852 | order2 = Extraordinary counsel in the [[Imperial Council (Austria)|Imperial Diet]] | term_start2 = May 31 | term_end2 = September 29, 1860 | order3 = Deputy in the [[Diet of Hungary]] | term_start3 = 1865 | term_end3 = 1869 | constituency3 = [[Krassó County]] | birth_date = June 27, 1812 | birth_place = [[Pest, Hungary|Pest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Kingdom of Hungary]], [[Austrian Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1880|5|5|1812|6|27|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Timișoara|Temeschwar (Timișoara)]], [[Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen|Transleithania]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | nationality = [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] (to 1867)
[[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] (from 1867) | profession = Landowner, jurist, civil servant, journalist, businessman | spouse = Laura Csernovich | relations = [[Anton Mocioni]] (brother)
[[Gheorghe Mocioni]] (brother)
[[Petar Čarnojević]] (father-in-law)
[[Alexandru Mocioni]] (nephew) }} '''Andrei Mocioni de Foen''' (also spelled '''Andrea de Mocioni''' or '''Andreiu Mocionĭ''', last name also '''Mocsonyi''', '''Mocsoni''', '''Mocionyi''' or '''Mocsony'''; {{lang-de|Andreas Mocioni de Foen}} or ''Andreas von Mocsonyi'', {{lang-hu|fényi Mocsonyi András}}; June 27, 1812 – April 23/May 5, 1880) was an [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] and [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Hungarian]] jurist, politician, and informal leader of the [[Romanians|ethnic Romanian]] community, one of the founding members of the [[Romanian Academy]]. Of a mixed [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] and [[Albanians|Albanian]] background, raised as a [[Church of Greece|Greek Orthodox]], he belonged to the [[Mocioni family]], which had been elevated to [[Hungarian nobility]]. He was brought up at his family estate in the [[Banat]], at [[Foeni]], where he joined the administrative apparatus, and identified as a Romanian since at least the 1830s. He rose to prominence during the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848]]: he was a supporter of the [[House of Lorraine]], trying to obtain increased autonomy for Banat Romanians in exchange for loyalism. The Austrians appointed Mocioni to an executive position over that region, but curbed his expectations by including the Banat as a whole into the [[Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar|Voivodeship of Serbia]]. This disappointment pushed Mocioni to renounce politics during much of the 1850s. The attempt by Austria to ensure a new administrative formula in the 1860s saw Mocioni's co-option into the [[Imperial Council (Austria)|Imperial Diet]]. He also organized, in 1860, a National Assembly in the Banat, an abortive project seeking to obtain autonomy on ethnic grounds. He then oscillated between [[ethnic federalism]] within a nominal Hungarian realm and full centralism in Austria's custody, while failing in his bid to promote [[election boycott]] as a political weapon. He had noted political rivalries with Romanians who sided with [[Liberalism and radicalism in Hungary|Hungarian radicalism]], in particular [[Eftimie Murgu]]. Serving one full term in the [[Diet of Hungary]], Mocioni also turned to cooperation with the Romanians of [[Principality of Transylvania (1711–1867)|Transylvania]], and helped [[Andrei Șaguna]] to reestablish an independent [[Metropolis of Transylvania|Transylvanian Metropolis]] for Romanian Orthodox Christians. Alongside his brothers [[Gheorghe Mocioni|Gheorghe]] and [[Anton Mocioni|Anton]], and his lawyer [[Vincențiu Babeș]], he founded the newspaper ''Albina'' of [[Vienna]]. The creation of [[Austria-Hungary]] and the Banat's absorption into the [[Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen]] were significant blows for Mocioni's nationalist-loyalist campaign. Mocioni withdrew to Foeni, ailing and out of the public eye for the final decade of his life. He was still a noted philanthropist and sponsor of the Romanian press, but had conflicts with [[Krassó County]] voters and the Romanian peasants on his estates, a matter which contributed to his voluntary isolation. He was survived by his wife Laura, daughter of [[Petar Čarnojević]], and by his nephew, the politician [[Alexandru Mocioni]]. ==Biography== ===Origins and early life=== The Mocionis were probably descended from Petru Mucină, an Aromanian (or "Macedo-Romanian") priest from [[Aspropotamos, Trikala|Aspropotamos in Thessaly]] or [[Moscopole]], who declared loyalty to the [[Habsburg Monarchy]] and served in the [[Great Turkish War]].Colta, p. 66; Deheleanu, p. 216. See also Bugariu, p. 399 He and one of his brothers were killed in action somewhere in the Banat.Deheleanu, p. 216 [[Archpriest]] Constantin Mocioni, or "Constantinus Motsonyi", who may have been Mucină's son, settled among the Greek Orthodox (Greek, Romanian, and Aromanian) community of [[Pest, Hungary|Pest]] in the 1740s.Berényi, pp. 213–214; Colta, p. 66; Deheleanu, pp. 216–217 Family documents suggest that he was originally from Moscopole, and that he died at 110 years of age; under his watch, the family established lucrative businesses and began purchasing estates in Hungary and the Banat.Berényi, pp. 22–23, 112, 213–214; Deheleanu, pp. 216–217; Tiron, pp. 28–29, 31–32 His two sons Andrei and Mihai were raised into the nobility by [[King of Hungary|King-Emperor]] [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]]: the former in February 1783, the latter in June 1798, after distinguished service in the [[War of the First Coalition]].Berényi, pp. 214–215; Colta, pp. 66–67, 83; Deheleanu, p. 217; Tiron, pp. 31–35 The Mocionis were thus one of some 200 Aromanian families to receive titles, and became integrated with the 12,500 Romanian noble families attested in Hungary by 1800 (from a total 340,000).Tiron, pp. 29, 31–32 Andrei the elder was killed in mysterious circumstances before he could receive his diploma, but this was granted to his wife.{{ro icon}} Ștefan Both, [http://adevarul.ro/locale/timisoara/foto-si-au-batut-joc-conacul-familiei-mocioni-foeni-fost-rand-baie-comunala-gradinita-depozit-sala-sport-discoteca-1_56250e6cf5eaafab2cd2b861/index.html "Cum și-au bătut joc de conacul familiei Mocioni de la Foeni. A fost pe rând baie comunală, grădiniță, depozit, sală de sport și discotecă"], in ''[[Adevărul]]'' (Timișoara edition), October 21, 2015 The more senior branch established by them became known as ''Mocioni de Foen'', or ''fényi Mocsonyi'', in reference to its core estate of [[Foeni|Foeni (Fény)]]. This was by contrast with Mihai's descendants, the ''armalist'' Mocionis, who did not hold a titular estate—although they built a manor at [[Birchiș|Birchiș (Marosberkes)]], they were mostly based in Pest, where they founded the Kefala Library.Colta, pp. 66–70 Andrei the second was a grandson of the original Andrei, born to lawyer Ioan Mocioni de Foen (1780–1854) and his wife Iuliana Panaiot (1787–1858).Tiron, pp. 28, 32 On his mother's side, Andrei had [[Albanians|Albanian]] roots.[[Theodor Capidan]], "Românii din Macedonia. Rolul Românilor Macedoneni în Ardeal. IV", in ''Cultura Poporului'', Nr. 30/1923, p. 1[[Atanasie Marian Marienescu]], "Macedo-Românii din Ungaria", in [[V. A. Urechia]], ''Albumul Macedo-Român'', p. 72. Bucharest: [[Editura Socec|Socecŭ, Sander & Teclu]], 1880. {{OCLC|45239179}} He had an elder brother, Petru, born in 1808, and two junior ones: [[Anton Mocioni|Anton]] and [[Gheorghe Mocioni|Gheorghe]] (born 1816 and 1823, respectively).Deheleanu, p. 219; Tiron, pp. 30, 31, 32 Other siblings included brothers George and Lucian (the latter of whom died young) and sister Ecaterina.Deheleanu, p. 219 Ioan and Iuliana together had as many as 11 other children.Berényi, p. 184; Deheleanu, p. 219 Andrei was simultaneously the uncle and cousin of writer [[Alexandru Mocioni]], born from a [[consanguine marriage]] between Ecaterina and her uncle Mihai Mocioni.Berényi, p. 137; Colta, pp. 71–74; Deheleanu, p. 218; Tiron, p. 32 {{Multiple image |align=left |direction=vertical |total_width=230 |image1=Mocioni de Foen coat of arms.svg |caption1=Mocioni de Foen coat of arms, granted 1783 |image2=Andrei Mocsonyi.jpg |caption2=Lithograph of Andrei Mocioni, ca. 1840 }} Andrei the younger was a native of Pest, but grew up mostly in Foeni where, according to scholar [[Păun Otiman]], he received "a profoundly Christian Orthodox education, inspired by Macedo-Romanian traditions and culture".Otiman, p. 27 Originally, the Mocionis only spoke Aromanian and Hungarian.Berényi, p. 214 Nevertheless, the family encouraged intercultural contacts, with Ioan speaking as many as eleven languages. According to the [[Serbs in Vojvodina|Banatian Serb]] journalist [[Mihailo Polit-Desančić]], the local Mocionis, including Andrei, also made a point of learning Serbian, and "sort of carried themselves like Serbs".Milin (2011), p. 383 Seen by his contemporaries as a man of outstanding culture and upbringing, Andrei had "perfect" command of Aromanian, Romanian, Hungarian, Serbian, as well as Latin, French, and German.Otiman, pp. 28–29. See also Bugariu, p. 399 Like his father, he took a law degree in 1828Tiron, p. 28 or 1832, from the [[Eötvös Loránd University|Royal University of Pest]].Berényi, p. 87; Bugariu, p. 399; Deheleanu, p. 219; Otiman, p. 28 He then worked in the local administration of Banat. In 1836, he was the second-ranked [[notary]] of [[Torontál County]], being appointed first [[pretor]] in 1843.Bugariu, p. 399; Deheleanu, p. 219; Tiron, p. 28 Ethnologist Elena Rodica Colta dates the Mocionis' definitive self-identification as Romanians to this period, noting that they believed the entire Aromanian ethnos to be a branch of the Romanian community.Colta, p. 71 During his time in Pest, Andrei began frequenting the literary salon organized by [[Atanasiu Grabovski de Apadia]] in [[Terézváros]], meeting with exponents of Aromanian and Romanian causes.Berényi, pp. 26–27, 118, 145, 189 While participating in Torontál's ''congregatio generalis'', Andrei Mocioni sat with the "conservative-progressive" side of the Romanian caucus, taking his distance from the [[Liberalism and radicalism in Hungary|revolutionary liberals]].Bugariu, p. 399; Deheleanu, pp. 219–220 Thanks in part to his contribution, Torontál remained a safe seat for the conservative club of [[István Széchenyi]], committed to "moderate progress" for the country at large, with "national conservation" for the Romanians. In 1847, he managed to obtain a seat in the [[Diet of Hungary]], for his brother Petru, obtaining him votes from conservative Hungarians, Serbs, [[Banat Bulgarians|Bulgarians]], [[Armenians in Hungary|Armenians]] and [[Banat Swabians|Swabians]].Bugariu, p. 399 ===1848 revolution and Banat leadership=== The same period saw him dragged into the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Austrian Empire|Austrian]] and [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848|Hungarian Revolutions]]. Like many Romanians, Mocioni supported the former's liberal reforms, and remained loyal to [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Franz Joseph I]], opposing the rise of [[Hungarian nationalism]]. This pitted him against the pro-Hungarian revolutionary [[Eftimie Murgu]], who enlisted the loyalties of various other Banatians.Deheleanu, p. 220 The [[Hungarian State (1849)|Hungarian State]] reacted by confiscating Mocioni's property and forcing him into exile.Bugariu, p. 399; Deheleanu, p. 220; Tiron, p. 29 By September 1849, he was in [[Vienna]], where he acted as a Romanian representative, alongside [[Ioan Dobran]] and [[Vincențiu Babeș]].Lițiu, p. 33 Petru Mocioni was also active there as a "man of trust" of the Banatian Romanians,Mureșan & Suciu, p. 107 presenting [[Franz Stadion, Count von Warthausen|Franz Stadion]] with a set of political proposals on their behalf.Ciorănescu, p. 218 Following the [[surrender at Világos]] and the resumption of Austrian control, Mocioni's loyalty was rewarded, and he was appointed supreme commissioner for the Banat, within the new [[Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar]].Bugariu, p. 399; Ciorănescu, p. 218; Deheleanu, p. 220; Mureșan & Suciu, p. 107; Tiron, pp. 29–30 As such, he governed directly over some 600,000 people. However, he disliked this arrangement, and, in December 1849, petitioned [[Prince Felix of Schwarzenberg]] to obtain the secession of Banat as an autonomous, Romanian, province.Tiron, p. 30 During his mandate, the administration was staffed with a growing number of Romanians. In tandem, his Mocioni relatives approached the Romanians of [[Principality of Transylvania (1711–1867)|Transylvania]], also loyalists, and together with them began pressing for a Romanian dukedom to be created out of Romanian territories in Hungary.Ciorănescu, p. 44; Milin (2011), p. 398. See also Berényi, pp. 200–201; Mureșan & Suciu, p. 107 The commissioner was also involved in such projects, proposing that a Romanian press be set up in [[Arad, Romania|Arad]], located on the Banat's traditional border with Transylvania and [[Partium]].Lițiu, pp. 37–38 By 1850, Mocioni was also campaigning to reestablish a [[Metropolis of Transylvania|Transylvanian (Romanian) Orthodox Metropolis]], fully separated from the [[Patriarchate of Karlovci]]. The cause had first been embraced by Petru in the 1840s. In 1852, he ultimately resigned as commissioner, expressing his protest toward the treatment of Romanians by the Austrian government.Deheleanu, p. 220; Tiron, p. 30 However, he was asked to reconsider by the authorities, who feared that they were becoming unpopular with the majority population. Although he did not resume his earlier posting, he went on to serve as president of the Central Commission in [[Timișoara|Temeschwar (Timișoara)]]; he was also a counsel for the [[Supreme Court (Austria)|Austrian Court of Cassation]].Tiron, p. 30. See also Deheleanu, p. 220 He resigned all positions in the state apparatus in 1856, and withdrew to Foeni. This decision was cemented in 1858 by the death of brother Petru, killed by his own landlord or doorman in Pest.Bugariu, p. 399; Deheleanu, pp. 219, 220, 221; Tiron, p. 30 The killing, which some authors see as a political assassination, ended with a celebrity trial in which [[Emanoil Gojdu]] represented the Mocionis as plaintiffs.Neș, p. 20 In 1859, at Foeni, Mocioni married a Serb coreligionist, Laura, the Countess Csernovich (Čarnojević)."Ce e nou?", in ''[[Familia (magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 33/1880, p. 211Deheleanu, pp. 219, 220; Tiron, p. 30 A woman of "outstanding beauty",Milin (2011), p. 382 she was also noted for collecting Ancient Roman coinsBabeșiu, pp. 179–180 and paintings with Roman subjects by Nicola Popescu."Pesta in 12 Noemvre n.", in ''Albina'', Nr. 87/1866, p. 3 Her father, ''[[Graf]]'' [[Petar Čarnojević]], had been an ally of the Hungarian revolutionaries; dispossessed and bankrupt, he moved to Foeni to live with the couple.Milin (2011), pp. 382–383 They also shared the manor with Alexandru and the other ''armalist'' Mocionis, who were similarly disappointed with Hungarian politics, and who progressively withdrew from Pest.Colta, pp. 74–75 Author [[Atanasie Marian Marienescu]] notes that Mocioni, "everywhere encouraged and supported by the Romanian [[intelligentsia]], became in all places a leader of the Romanians in national and church causes, and this leadership was recognized by his brothers as well." From about 1860, he dedicated himself to the [[national awakening of Romania]]ns, networking between the Austrian subjects in the Banat, Transylvania, and the [[Duchy of Bukovina]], and those residing in the newly formed [[United Principalities]]. In November 1860, as [[Alexander von Mensdorff-Pouilly, Prince Dietrichstein von Nicolsburg|Count Mensdorff-Pouilly]] was sent over to report to Franz Joseph on the demands of Banat Romanians, Mocioni called in and organized a National Assembly. This demanded the creation of a Banat Captaincy, and, when the request was denied, an administrative incorporation with Transylvania.Bugariu, pp. 399–400; Tiron, p. 30. See also Ciorănescu, pp. 89–90; Milin (2010), p. 21; Mureșan & Suciu, p. 107; Otiman, p. 28 He noted that Romanians needed to form a singular "moral body", "called upon as a nation to partake in Austria's constitutional life."Ciorănescu, p. 90 In his ''Memorandum to the Throne'', Mocioni also theorized that the Banat was an "individuality" distinct from the Serbian and Hungarian regions, and suggested that "never-ending problems" would result from its continued amalgamation.Milin (2010), p. 21 ===Imperial Diet and church separation=== [[File:Ethnic map of the Serbian Voivodeship and the Banat Military Frontier, 1855.svg|thumb|330px|Ethnic map of the [[Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar|Serbian Voivodeship]] and [[Banat Military Frontier]] (''Mg.''), also marking the traditional borders of Banat. Serbs in red, Romanians in yellow, Hungarians in green. [[Danube Swabians|Danube]] and [[Banat Swabians]] in black, [[Czechs of Romania|Czechs]] and [[Slovaks in Serbia|Slovaks]] in blue, [[Banat Bulgarians]] in pink]] On May 31, 1860,Păcățian, p. 269 Mocioni was co-opted by the [[Imperial Council (Austria)|Imperial Diet]], which contemplated administrative reforms based on new ethnic arrangements. He was an "extraordinary counsel", alongside [[Andrei Șaguna]] of Transylvania and [[Nicolae de Petrino]] of Bukovina, supporting regional autonomy and the reestablishment and a Romanian Metropolis.''Mitropolitul...'', pp. 222, 327; Bugariu, p. 399; Deheleanu, pp. 220–221; Lupaș, pp. 187–189; Otiman, p. 28; Păcățian, ''passim''; Tiron, p. 30 By origin, all three were in fact Aromanians.Deheleanu, p. 221 Reportedly, both Șaguna and Mocioni objected to Diet being non-democratic, and, on this point, agreed with [[György Apponyi]] that the delegates only represented themselves. Their objection was registered, but they were asked by [[Archduke Rainer Ferdinand of Austria|Archduke Rainer]] not to insist on this point.Păcățian, pp. 269–270 Seen from his regional constituency, Mocioni was also one of two representatives of the Voivodeship, including the Banat. The other was a Serb prelate, [[Samuilo Maširević]].Păcățian, pp. 268–269, 270 By September 1860, Mocioni clarified that he considered himself a legitimate Banat and "people's" representative.Păcățian, p. 278 On June 6, Mocioni was elected to the Budget Committee, and from this position campaigned to have Romanian Orthodox churches subsidized on par with other state-recognized religions.Păcățian, pp. 270, 274, 278–279 Proclaiming the equality of nations against demands for Hungarian hegemony, he found himself debating the issue with [[György Majláth (1786–1861)|György Majláth]], who accused him of fostering the rebellious doctrines of [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]]. Mocioni defended his ideas as mainstream, arguing that equality had been promised by Franz Joseph himself.Stefan Malfèr, "Les représentations de Garibaldi en Autriche", in Jean-Yves Frétigné, Paul Pasteur (eds.), ''Changer d'époque, n° 23. Garibaldi: modèle, contre-modèle'', p. 114. Rouen: Publications des universités de Rouen et du Havre, 2011. {{ISBN|978-2-87775-508-5}}. See also Ciorănescu, p. 89 In the end, Mocioni sided with the "centralists", who supported [[proportional representation]] within a centralized Austria; Petrino, a "federalist", wanted regional decentralization on the basis of old laws, which, while favoring Bukovinans, would have left Romanians in Hungary underrepresented as a group.Lupaș, p. 189; Păcățian, pp. 277–279 The two made common cause in their opposition to a projected union between Bukovina and [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria|Austrian Galicia]].Păcățian, p. 275 Mocioni's mandate ended with the Diet recall on September 29, 1860. He had failed in his bid to secure Banat autonomy: the region, alongside all of the Voivodeship, was re-annexed to the Hungarian crown in December 1860. In April 1861, Mocioni persuaded the Banat Romanians to boycott future elections for the reestablished Hungarian Diet. This decision was overturned later that year, when a new ethnic assembly passed a resolution calling for single Romanian candidatures, supported by all voters.Bugariu, p. 400 Mocioni himself was elected for [[Krassó County|Krassó (Caraș) County]], at [[Lugoj|Lugoj (Lugos)]]. His rival was Murgu, who sided with the [[Address Party]] and supported incorporation with Hungary. Mocioni, perceived as the Romanian nationalist candidate, won 621 votes to 94.Berényi, pp. 102–103. See also Wlad, pp. 39–42 However, he had not agreed to be listed as a candidate,Wlad, p. 39 and immediately renounced his seat.Ovidiu Emil Iudean, Alexandru Onojescu, "Politics, Nationalism, and Parliamentarianism: Romanian Representatives in the Budapest Parliament (1861–1918)", in ''Transylvanian Review'', Vol. XXII, Issue 4, Winter 2013, p. 6; Papio Ilariano, pp. 4–5, 68 In his address, Mocioni explained that "he had nothing in common with the Hungarian diet of Pest, since he had never intended to become a Hungarian."Papio Ilariano, p. 4 He also had a publicized row with the Temeschwar [[Burgrave]], the pro-Hungarian [[Petru Cermena]], but their dispute was ultimately patched up by Babeș.Babeșiu, pp. 173–174 The Diet itself was dissolved later that year. Mocioni's solution to these setbacks was the attempted creation of a de facto "political body" and "[[crown land]]" for all Romanians of the Empire. In the parallel debate over church affairs, Șaguna, the designated Metropolitan, had Mocioni as one of his "most ardent supporters",Hitchins, p. 13 one "fighting like a virile lion for the hierarchic separation"."Epistolele parochului betranu, XIV", in ''Biseric'a si Scóla'', Nr. 51/1887, pp. 412–413 Mediating between the Karlovci Patriarch [[Josif Rajačić]] and his Romanian clergy, he proposed to convene a representative [[synod]] on the issue of separation, knowing that it would favor the Romanians.''Mitropolitul...'', p. 229; Hitchins, p. 13; Lupaș, pp. 193, 258 The Patriarch resisted this move and suspended the negotiations, arguing that "the [Serb] nation would have me stoned to death".''Mitropolitul...'', p. 229; Lupaș, p. 193 Rajačić's death in late 1861 created confusion among the Serb bishops, empowering Mocioni to network and campaign for the national schism.Bocșan (2011), pp. 366–367; Hitchins, pp. 14–16; Mureșan & Suciu, p. 108 He outlined his political manifesto for autonomy in articles for ''[[Gazeta Transilvaniei]]'' of [[Brașov|Corona]], as well as in reports addressed to Franz Joseph.Otiman, p. 28; Mureșan & Suciu, pp. 107–108 That year, with Șaguna and [[Alexandru Sterca-Șuluțiu]], Mocioni established [[Asociația Transilvană pentru Literatura Română și Cultura Poporului Român|ASTRA Society]], which promoted Romanian identity and culture, created despite continued chicanery from Hungarian officials."Buletinul ''Astrei'' Satu-Mare. ''Astra'' la Abrud", in ''Afirmarea'', Nr. 9/1938, p. 109 He also placed a bid for ASTRA's presidency, but lost to Șaguna.Lupaș, p. 748 He was more successful in his campaigning for an Orthodox metropolis, set up in December 1864; from 1865, it incorporated Banatian Romanian churches as the [[Diocese of Caransebeș]].Bocșan (2011), pp. 366–367; Tiron, pp. 30–31. See also Bugariu, p. 400; Hitchins, pp. 17–20 Already in 1862, Mocioni, Șaguna, and [[Eudoxiu Hurmuzachi]] had managed to obtain Franz Joseph's sympathy on this issue.''Mitropolitul...'', pp. 327–328; Hitchins, pp. 16–17; Lupaș, pp. 271–272, 278; Mureșan & Suciu, p. 108 He wrote about this victory in ''[[Telegraful Român]]'' of Transylvania and ''Concordia'' of Bukovina, persuading "right-believing Romanians" not to participate in the election of a Rajačić replacement.''Mitropolitul...'', p. 328; Bocșan (2011), p. 366; Lupaș, p. 272 Nevertheless, Mocioni was disappointed with Șaguna, who did not back his plan for creating a new [[Archdiocese of Timișoara|bishopric at Temeschwar]].Bocșan (2011), pp. 366–368; P. Ionescu, "Observări la rĕspunsul Prea Cuv. Sale Dlui arhimandrit Dr. Ilarion Pușcariu", in ''Foaia Diecesană'', Nr. 28/1901, p. 5 During this clash, he withdrew his financial support for the church historian [[Nicolae Tincu-Velea]], who had to print his works with ASTRA.Bocșan (2011), pp. 367–368 ===Hungarian Diet=== Returning to Arad, Mocioni helped establish there a National Culture and Enlightenment Association, presided upon by [[Prokopije Ivačković]] and Anton Mocioni. It received his collection of historical documents, and appointed him a delegate to Vienna, to thank the emperor for supporting Romanian culture."Ungari'a. Prim'a adunare generala a Associatiunei natiunale in Aradu, pentru cultur'a si conversarea poporului romanu (Continuare lá Nr. 39)", in ''[[Telegraful Român]]'', Nr. 40/1863, p. 164 In 1863, his philanthropy expanded. He donated his only source of income, the revenue of Foeni, to the famine-stricken population of that village, and even ran into debt in his effort to provide for them.Bugariu, p. 400; Deheleanu, p. 221 He was also interested in [[horse breeding]], and one of his steeds became the ancestor of an equine string that populated much of Foeni.C. G. Wrangel, ''Ungarns Pferdezucht in Wort und Bild. Vierter Band: Die ungarische Landespferdezucht; Die Privatgestüte. Zweiter Teil'', pp. 22–23. Stuttgart: Verlag von Schickhardt & Ebner, 1895. {{OCLC|312705921}} For a while, the Romanians of Banat continued to plead with the emperor for Romanian self-rule in the Banat. One such petition, circulated in December 1863, also asked Franz Joseph to surround himself with Romanian advisers, including "Andrea de Mocioni, lord of Foeni", a man distinguished by "political, patriotic, and national virtues"."Plansórea Romaniloru Banatiani (incheiere din Nrulu trecutu)", in ''[[Foaia pentru Minte, Inimă și Literatură|Foaia pentru Minte, Anima si Literatura]]'', Nr. 29/1863, p. 207 As noted by historian Tudor-Radu Tiron, the restoration of Hungarian rule ultimately pushed the Mocionis back into Hungarian politics, which explains why Andrei, Anton and Gheorghe all took seats in the last Diet of Hungary (1865).Tiron, p. 31 Alexandru also won a [[Tormac|Rittberg]] seat in that legislature, becoming known as the theoretician of [[national liberalism]], and main proponent of a Nationalities Bill, which aimed at validating autonomous units for the Romanians in Hungary.Berényi, pp. 215–220; Nicolae Bocșan, "Liberalism and Nationalism in Alexandru Mocsonyi's Parliamentary Activity (1865–1871)", in ''Transylvanian Review'', Vol. XXII, Issue 4, Winter 2013, pp. 17–24; Ciorănescu, p. 92; Deheleanu, pp. 222–223; Milin (2010), pp. 21–28 By then, the Mocionis' contribution to the national cause was being recognized in the United Principalities, customarily known as the "[[Principality of Romania]]". From January 1865, he was an honorary member of the nationalist ''Bucovina'' Society.D. Murărașu, "Comentarii eminesciene 1866–1874. ''La mormântul lui Aron Pumnul''", in [[Mihai Eminescu]], ''Opere I. Poezii (I)'', p. 269. Bucharest: Grai și Suflet – Cultura Națională, 1995. {{ISBN|973-9232-07-8}} On April 22, 1866, the Romanian Regency appointed Andrei Mocioni a founding member of the [[Romanian Academy]] (or "Romanian Literary Society", as it was known at the time).Bugariu, p. 400; Otiman, ''passim''; Tiron, pp. 28, 31 He was inducted as a Banat representative, alongside Babeș—who, in 1883, wrote Mocioni's biography.Otiman, ''passim''; Tiron, p. 31. See also Bugariu, p. 400; Lupaș, p. 271 From 1861, the Mocionis and Babeș had cooperated in countering Hungarian nationalist propaganda abroad, publicizing the Romanian point of view. According to Babeș, their effort was sabotaged by [[Abdolonyme Ubicini]], [[István Türr]], and [[Giovenale Vegezzi Ruscalla]], who wanted a Hungarian–Romanian alliance against Austria; but also found backing from [[László Teleki]] of the [[Resolution Party]].Babeșiu, pp. 174–176 With his parallel career as a lawyer, Babeș also helped the Mocionis win back 5 million [[Hungarian forint|forint]] from their Hungarian debtors, and was thereafter their trusted adviser.Cosma, pp. 267–268 {{Multiple image |align=right |direction=vertical |total_width=370 |image1=O scena in camer'a Ungariei sub efeptulu vorbirei dlui Alisandru Mocioni (2 Juliu 1870), Gura Satului, 17 iul 1870.png |caption1=[[Alexandru Mocioni]] speaking in the [[Diet of Hungary]], July 1870 carton in the [[Arad, Romania|Arad]] magazine ''Gura Satului'' |image2=Foeni1.jpg |caption2=Mocioni's Foeni manor, 2006 photograph }} Later in 1866, echoes of Mocioni's "Captaincy" project were discernible in the radical proposal advanced in the Diet by Babeș, [[Sigismund Popoviciu]], and [[Iosif Hodoșiu]]: it recognized subjection to the Hungarian crown and government, but sought to redefine Hungary on the basis of [[ethnic federalism]] and [[corporatism]].Milin (2010), p. 23. See also Neș, pp. 113–114 These efforts also failed. By September 1866, Mocioni and Babeș began speaking out in the Diet about the wish of Austrian Romanians to be united with the Principality of Romania.Sorin Liviu Damean, "Români și maghiari în contextul războiului austro–prusian (1866)", in ''Analele Universității din Craiova, Seria Istorie'', Vol. XVI, Issue 1, 2011, pp. 280–281 The 1866–1867 interval was a great disappointment for the various schools of Romanian nationalism: the return of Hungarian nationalism was unopposed following the [[Austro-Prussian War]], and the [[Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867|''Ausgleich'' of 1867]] created [[Austria-Hungary]], including most Romanian-inhabited areas into the [[Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen]]. Mocioni was especially affected by the outcome.Bugariu, p. 400; Tiron, p. 31 In the months following the new arrangement, Mocioni and Babeș participated in the drafting of another protest, also signed by the Diet's Serb, Slovak and "[[Ruthenians|Ruthenian]]" deputies. The resolution, which demanded guarantees for the minorities, was supposed to be read by Mocioni. He stepped down to make way for a more popular deputy, the Serb [[Milán Manojlovics]]."Manifestatiune colective in cestiunea de nationalitate", in ''[[Românul|Romanulu]]'', December 22, 1867, p. 1096 Brother Anton Mocioni, alongside Serbs [[Stevan Branovački]] and [[Svetozar Miletić]], continued to back the campaign, proposing to divide Hungary into six ethnic-based provinces.Neș, pp. 15, 114–116, 132–133 ===Final withdrawal=== In 1869, Andrei Mocioni withdrew from all activism and returned to Foeni. That year, an analysis in ''Der Wanderer'' newspaper noted that "although Andrea Mocioni will forever remain the true leader" of the Romanian caucus, Alexandru was emerging as the tactician, and moderating the Romanians' resistance to Hungarian nationalism."Varietati. Indreptare", in ''Albina'', Nr. 10/1869, p. 2 By then, the various factions seeking to form a [[Romanian National Party]] had only managed to establish a Transylvanian caucus and a Banatian one. The latter, presided upon by Anton Mocioni, recognized Hungarian rule and sought to obtain Romanian rights within its jurisdiction.Neș, pp. 132–133 An 1872 report to his partisans also claimed that Andrei and the other Mocionis were "disgusted" and "demoralized" by the behavior of Romanian electors in Lugoj and Krassó, who acted as "proselytes of the [Hungarian] government"."Lugosiu, 4 fauru 1872", in ''Albina'', Nr. 9/1872, p. 2 Mocioni also continued to be active as a sponsor and philanthropist, providing funds for Babeș's ethnological work, and for the Viennese Romanian newspaper, ''Albina''.Cosma, pp. 263–268; Deheleanu, pp. 221–222; Munteanu, p. 64; Neș, p. 298; Otiman, p. 28 He and his brothers published and wrote for the latter sheet, alongside Babeș,Berényi, pp. 202–204; Cosma, pp. 264–266 while also financing pro-Romanian campaigns in the German-language journal ''Ost und West''.''Mitropolitul...'', pp. 331–332 Together with [[Visarion Roman]] and [[Partenie Cosma]], they established in 1871 the Albina Bank of [[Sibiu]], providing credit for Romanian businesses.Neș, p. 136 At the time, Mocioni also provided funds in hopes of creating a Romanian regional theater, and became [[Godparent|godfather]] of Andrei, the child of actors [[Mihail Pascaly|Mihail]] and [[Matilda Pascaly]].Berényi, pp. 56, 162. See also Neș, p. 228 The family as a whole provided a scholarship fund for disadvantaged children, managed by Babeș.Berényi, pp. 210, 220–221, 237; Bugariu, p. 400; Deheleanu, p. 221; Neș, pp. 301–302 Noted recipients include writer [[Gruia Liuba Murgu]],Cosma, p. 270 biologist [[Victor Babeș]], and lawyer [[Coriolan Brediceanu]].Berényi, p. 220 The former deputy and the [[Magyar Posta|Hungarian post]] had an unsolved dispute about the creation of a Foeni post office, which the officials viewed as too costly. Mocioni took the [[postmaster]] examination and, at his own expense, erected a building which, with its [[mahogany]] furniture and silver [[inkwell]]s, was recognized as "the most elegant post office"."Diverse. Biroulu postalu celu mai elegantu", in ''[[Gazeta de Transilvania|Gazet'a Transilvaniei]]'', Nr. 54/1880, p. 3 Mocioni was still pressed by his friends to make a return to politics. He refused on principle, but allowed for a theoretical possibility: "I shall no longer fight and sacrifice myself to the four winds, but will patiently wait for a national regeneration to begin, if ever." A local tradition, recorded in 1905 by the newspaper ''[[Tribuna (Romania)|Tribuna]]'', noted that, by then, he and his Serb wife were detested by the local Romanians, who once attacked the manor and shattered its windows."Concertul de la Foenĭ", in ''[[Tribuna (Romania)|Tribuna]]'', Nr. 37/1905, p. 2 According to a notice in the Arad Orthodox paper ''Biseric'a si Scóla'', Mocioni was also driven away from religious affairs after "a mean gossiper libeled him, out of the blue and without a shred of truthfulness". Mocioni's health was failing, and for this reason he never attended any session of the Romanian Academy.Otiman, p. 28 From 1879, Mocioni's disease worsened, and, once bedridden, he was taken to Temeschwar to be under specialist care. Mocioni died on May 5 (April 23), 1880. Although some sources give his death place as Foeni, contemporary reports have it that he died in Temeschwar, after having lapsed into a brief coma, and while looked after by his wife Laura. Their marriage had produced no heirs. ===Legacy=== [[File:Cripta familiei Mocioni din Foeni.jpg|thumb|380px|Mocioni crypt in Foeni, 2015 photograph]] Mocioni's body was taken to Foeni for an Orthodox burial at the common Serb–Romanian church, which he and his wife had furnished."Noutăți. Intoleranță", in ''Tribuna Poporului'', Nr. 110/1900, p. 3 Laura inherited all his wealth, which sparked a Mocioni family feud. Already a licensed postal worker, she continued Mocioni's work as a postmaster. She died on the estate in August 1892, aged 53,"Ce e nou? Necrolog", in ''[[Familia (magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 32/1892, p. 382 and was buried at his side. In her late years, she had carried on with Mocioni philanthropy work, but only servicing the local Serb community and punishing Romanian ingratitude. According to ''Tribuna'', the "new generation" of Romanians, "more enlightened than the earlier one", was expressing shame and regret for having alienated her. By then, a scandal had erupted over Mocioni's remains. The church remained a property of the Karlovci Patriarchy, which in 1900 refused to hand over the body for reburial in the Mocioni mausoleum. It cited texts which condemned the separation in death of husband and wife, but the Romanian press suspected that such resistance was proof of "intolerant" [[Serb nationalism]]. A separation was eventually made, and Andrei was reburied in the new location. The various Mocioni estates went to brothers Alexandru and Eugen. Some were inherited by Eugen's sons, before passing to Ecaterina Mocioni and her husband, Jenő, [[Teleki family|Count Teleki]]; others went to the Bukovinan baron [[Ioan Mocsony-Stârcea]], who was Alexandru's adoptive son.Colta, pp. 77–83 The core manor at Foeni was nevertheless inherited by the [[Csávossy]] counts, while his horses continued to be bred by the Austrians Jakob Haas and Ludwig Deutsch. The property was pillaged by peasants during the [[Aster Revolution|revolutionary events]] which marked the collapse of Austria-Hungary in 1918. According to one Romanian account, this incident provided the [[Hungarian Royal Gendarmerie]] with an excuse to murder Romanians.Nicolae Bocșan, "The Banatian Revolution from the Autumn of 1918 in the Collective Memory {{sic}}", in ''Transylvanian Review'', Vol. XXIV, Issue 4, Winter 2015, p. 29 Most other assets were kept by the surviving family following the establishment of [[Greater Romania]], when Anton Jr bought back the Foeni mansion, hoping to turn it into a cultural club. According to historian Vicențiu Bugariu, by 1930 Andrei Mocioni was already forgotten, a victim of "ignorance and indifference". This trend was censured by the Banat politician [[Sever Bocu]]. Although a critic of "Mocionist" conservatism in Austria-Hungary, during the interwar he became noted for his work to preserve and shed light on the family's contribution as a "moral dynasty".Munteanu, pp. 8, 20, 47, 51–52, 58, 64–65, 91 Bocu wrote Andrei Mocioni's profile as a study in national pedagogy,Mureșan & Suciu, p. 90 declaring that any Banatian unaware of the Mocionis' role "is a Banatian in name only".Munteanu, p. 48 Mocioni, or any other of his relatives, is also mentioned in the [[Banat Romanian dialect|dialectical Banatian]] poetry of the interwar. Samples include [[Gheorghe Gârda]]'s ''Că tăt Bănatu-i fruncea!'' ("And Yet the Banat Is Tops") and [[Cassian R. Munteanu]]'s ''Vicejî noștri'' ("Our Braves").Ioan Viorel Boldureanu, Simion Dănilă, [[Cornel Ungureanu]], ''Antologia literaturii dialectale bănățene (poezie, proză, teatru); 1891–2011'', pp. 61, 71. Timișoara: [[West University of Timișoara|Editura Universității de Vest]], 2011. {{ISBN|978-973-125-339-8}} With the death of Anton Jr in 1943, the direct Mocioni lineage was extinguished; however, interest in the family was still kept alive by Bocu's nephew, the scholar Ion D. Suciu.Mureșan & Suciu, pp. 89–90, 92–94, 106 In the 1950s, the estates were subject to [[Nationalization in Romania|nationalization]] under the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]], which turned the Foeni complex into a public bathhouse, and then into a storage room for chemicals. Following the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]], the mansion was re-purposed as a cultural club and mainly functioned as a disco, before being taken over by the local town hall. The communist and post-communist periods saw the Mocioni inheritance falling into disrepair, and the deposited collections were still being looted in 2003.Colta, pp. 66–67, 78 In the latter period, busts of Andrei and Alexandru Mocioni were installed in Timișoara's Scudier Park.Lajos Kakucs, "De la Fântâna Pașei de pe lângă Mănăstirea Dervișilor până la Parcul Rozelor. Contribuții la istoria parcurilor din Timișoara", in ''Analele Banatului.
