{{Infobox person | name = David Rose | image = | caption = | birth_date = 1892 | birth_place = [[Jerusalem]] | birth_name = | death_date = {{death year and age|1986|1892}} | death_place = | residence = [[New York City]] | nationality = United States | education = | occupation = real estate developer | known_for = co-founder of Rose Associates | religion = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = | family = [[Samuel B. Rose]] (brother)
[[Frederick P. Rose]] (nephew)
[[Daniel Rose (real estate developer)|Daniel Rose]] (nephew)
[[Jonathan F. P. Rose]] (great-nephew)
[[David S. Rose]] (great-nephew)
[[Gideon Rose]] (great-nephew) | website = }} '''David Rose''' (1892–1986) was an American real estate developer and philanthropist who co-founded Rose Associates. ==Biography== Rose was born to a [[Jewish]] family in [[Jerusalem]][https://www.nytimes.com/1986/07/18/obituaries/david-rose.html New York Times: "DAVID ROSE"] July 18, 1986 one of six siblings. His family immigrated in the 1890s[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ysPL1vn5dQ BuildingNY: "The Life of Jonathan F. P. Rose"] October 10, 2012 and he then worked as a sales catalog buyer for a clothing store working in the [[Garment District, Manhattan|Garment District]] in New York City when - inspired by an uncle who purchased real estate[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Frederick+P.+Rose+dies+at+75.-a057386597 Real Estate Weekly: "Frederick P. Rose dies at 75"] September 22, 1999 - he founded Roses Associates with his brother, Samuel B., in 1927. In 1928, they completed their first building, a six-story, 218-unit building and within two years had completed more than 900 apartments. In 1930, they built the 500-unit Academy Apartments in the [[Bronx]], the first apartment building built of [[reinforced concrete]]. After the Depression, they began building apartments in [[Manhattan]]. One of his most prominent buildings was the Bankers Trust Company at 280 Park Avenue at 48th Street. The Rose family went on to become one of the most established and prominent real estate families in New York City in the 20th century (along with the [[Joseph Durst|Dursts]], the [[Samuel J. LeFrak|Lefraks]], the [[Jack Rudin|Rudins]], and the [[Laurence Tisch|Tisch family]]). In 2006, Rose Associates, managed over 31,000 apartments in New York City including [[Stuyvesant Town]] and [[Peter Cooper Village]].[http://observer.com/2006/12/the-rose-family/#ixzz34iGQxZUW New York Observer: "The Rose Family" By Jason Horowitz] December 18, 2006[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/09/nyregion/09families.html?_r=0 New York Times: "In City Real Estate, Old Clans Are Shrewd Again" By CHARLES V. BAGLI] February 8, 2010 ==Philanthropy== Rose was dedicated to supporting the development of new medical devices. He financed the design and construction of the first [[hyperbaric chamber]] in New York City at [[Mount Sinai Hospital (Manhattan)|Mount Sinai Hospital]]. He established the Foundation for Medical Technology, which finances medical instrumentation research; and he funded Dr. [[Willem Kolff]] in the development of the first production portable, artificial kidney. Rose also contributed to the building of [[Hadassah Hospital]] in Jerusalem and the [[Salk Institute for Biological Studies]] in [[La Jolla, California]]. He also served as a trustee of the [[New School for Social Research]] and of the Bronx [[YM-YWHA]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://findingaids.cul.columbia.edu/ead/nnc-a/ldpd_8972723/summary Rose Associates, Inc. Records, 1935-2004, (bulk 1935-1983) Held in the Dept. of Drawings & Archives, Avery Architectural & Fine Arts Library, Columbia University, New York City] {{DEFAULTSORT:Rose, David}} [[Category:1892 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:American real estate businesspeople]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Rose family]]

{{Infobox person | name = Elmedin Ademi | image = Elmedin Ademi.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1988|6|26}} | nationality = Albanian | occupation = {{hlist|Entrepreneur}} | years_active = 2008 | known = Founder of [[Screen Media (advertising company)]], CEO of Eurovia, Partner of ama Caffe Macedonia | title = Chairman and CEO of Adel Holding | spouse = Arbe Ademi | children = 2 | relatives = [[Abdilaqim Ademi]] (cousin) }}
Elmedin Ademi is an Albanian [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]] in Macedonia. He is the founder and CEO of [[Screen Media (advertising company)|Screen Media]] and a co-founder of the construction company EUROVIA. Since 2015, Screen Media is the first in the advertising industry, based on the annual turnover base. Elmedin was named as one of the most important Business Entrepreneurs in Macedonia in 2015.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.chamber.mk/en/index.php/press-center/item/730-entrepreneur-of-the-year-awards|title="Entrepreneur of the Year" Awards|last=Administrator|access-date=2018-03-01|language=en-gb}}</ref> In 2016 he was appointed as the winner of the national prize<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessawardseurope.com/vote/entry/125/15626|title=The European Business Awards|website=www.businessawardseurope.com|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref> for Macedonia at the European Business Awards<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mia.mk/en/Inside/RenderSingleNews/61/133330189|title=14 Macedonian companies named national champions in European Business Awards|work=MIA|access-date=2018-03-01|language=en-gb}}</ref>. The England Foundation, ACCOLA<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://accola.co.uk/track-record.php|title=ACCOLA {{!}} Track Record|website=accola.co.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref>, in 2017 in partnership opportunities engaged professional evaluates and Ademi's businesses valued at 12 million euros<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmg/mk/pdf/Investment-in-Macedonia-2017.pdf|title=Investment in Macedonia 2017 – KPMG in Macedonia|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== Early life and education == He was born on [[June 26]], 1988 in the city of [[Tetovo]]. He has completed secondary school in the hometown of Tetovo. Performs studies at the [[South East European University|University of South East European]] at Computer Science (SEEU).
At age 13, he developed an interest in computers. He taught computer programming himself and when he was 16, he launched several web sites for various companies in Macedonia.
== Infancy == In 2008 it started with Private Business in the field of marketing, respectively advertising with [[Out-of-home advertising|outdoor advertising]], [[Screen Media (advertising company)|Screen Media]], being one of the most successful in Macedonia<ref name=":0" /> in this field. In order to strengthen the leadership of the family company, during 2012 his family will hand over to Eurovia, a family company established since 1978, specialized in the design and construction. Since then, he has focused on [[Construction|construction work]] and [[real estate]].
== Commitment and establishment of other businesses in Macedonia == <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://shop.enea.mk|title=Enea Shop|website=Enea Shop|language=mk|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref> In 2016, he signed an exclusive agreement with the New Coun Countrytry – Tirana to be a general importer of all AMA products (caffe, capsule, iced cafe, turkish cafe) for Macedonia. At the beginning of 2018 launches a commercial [[Online shopping|online project]] with coffee products, respectively the brands [https://www.caffitaly.com/ Cafeitaly] and [http://amacaffe.com/company/ Ama], where it will have tremendous success.
== Reference == <references />
== External links == # [http://screenmedia.mk/new/?team_member=elmedin-ademi Elmedin Ademi në Screen Media] # [http://www.sakte.net/nipi-i-abdilaqim-ademit-te-bdi-se-ne-mesin-e-10-shqiptareve-me-te-pasur-ne-maqedoni-foto/ Nipi i Abdilaqim Ademit të BDI-së në mesin e 10 shqiptarëve më të pasur në Maqedoni] # [http://chamber.mk/en/index.php/press-center/item/730-entrepreneur-of-the-year-awards "Entrepreneur of the Year" Awards] # [https://www.aktuale.mk/237180-2/ NEZIRI: ÇMIMET PËR SIPËRMARRËSIT -NXITJE SHTESË PËR REZULTATE MË TË MIRA EKONOMIKE] # [http://portalb.mk/102703-zbulohen-bizneset-e-familjes-se-abdilaqim-ademit-te-bdi-se/ Zbulohen bizneset e familjes së Abdilaqim Ademit të BDI-së] # [http://en.inbox7.mk/?p=1007 THE OTHER SIDE OF ADVERTISEMENTS: WHO IS BEHIND THE BUSINESS WITH BILLBOARDS IN MACEDONIA?] # [http://oemvp.org/u-ndane-cmimet-per-sipermarresit-e-vitit/ U ndanë çmimet për sipërmarrësit e vitit] # [https://telegrafi.com/zyrtaret-shqiptare-biznese-milioneshe/ Zyrtarët shqiptarë me biznese milionëshe!] # [http://shqipmedia.com/elmedin-ademi-zgjidhet-menaxheri-me-i-suksesshem-ne-maqedoni-foto/ Elmedin Ademi zgjidhet menaxheri më i suksesshëm në Maqedoni] # [http://www.independent.mk/articles/20580/Citizens+Encouraged+to+Help+Flood+Affected+Tetovo+Region Citizens Encouraged to Help Flood Affected Tetovo Region] # [http://shqipmedia.com/ama-caffe-kapsulat-tani-mund-ti-porositni-ne-internet/ “Ama Caffe” kapsulat tani mund ti porositni në internet] __INDEX__ __NEWSECTIONLINK__

{{Multiple issues| {{one source|date=September 2009}} {{news release|date=September 2009}} }}
'''Event to knowledge''' ('''E2K''') is an [[accounting]] [[Metric (mathematics)|metric]] that measures the time from when an event occurs to when the responsible person knows about it. The shorter the average E2K time, the more timely an organization’s financial information will be.
== Importance of E2K ==
Timeliness is one of the most important characteristics of financial information. The more timely information is, the more relevant it is to the reader. E2K helps organizations focus and improve their internal accounting processes.
E2K measures a number of events. Firstly, it considers the time for a sub-ledger or supporting system to record an event. If a sub-ledger performs no reporting on its own and it posts to the [[general ledger]] on a [[:wikt:batch|batch]] basis (nightly, weekly, monthly, etc.); then this will elongate the E2K time.
The faster the general ledger can report the impact of an event, the smaller the E2K value. Waiting for all accounting journals to be posted, balancing, [[bank reconciliation|reconciliation]] and producing paper reports adds to the E2K time.
There are two key E2K measures, the maximum and average E2K values. The maximum value is the time from when the first [[Financial transaction|transaction]] is entered in a system during a new fiscal period to when it is reported. An average E2K time may be for an entire system or a sub-component. For example, E2K can be reported by each sub-ledger (accounts payable, payroll, manufacturing, etc.) or for the entire system.
== Best E2K practice ==
Organizations can reduce their E2K time through a number of strategies: 1. Implementing and upgrading systems to take advantage of faster close cycles 2. Use of [[workflow]] technologies to communicate exceptions and critical events to those responsible 3. Reporting Marts and the like away from the [[OLTP]] system for internal reporting 4. Adjust accounting cycles to natural business cycles. 5. [[Benchmarking|Benchmark]] and set targets to improve current practice.
== References == Event to knowledge Frank Potter. CMA Management. Hamilton:Jul/Aug 2001. Vol. 75, Iss. 5, p. 33–37 (6 pp.)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Event To knowledge}} [[Category:Management accounting]]

{{Infobox rail line |box_width = 280px |name = F Market & Wharves |color = F0E68C |image = Car 1015 (Illinois Terminal) on Market Street.jpg |image_width = 300px |caption = Car 1015, one of San Francisco's original double-ended PCC streetcars, on Market Street near the Ferry Building, painted in the colors of the Illinois Terminal Railroad (St. Louis) |type = [[Heritage streetcar]] |system = [[San Francisco Municipal Railway]] |locale = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] |start = [[Jones and Beach Station|Jones and Beach]]
''[[Fort Mason]]'' (planned) |end = [[Castro Street Station|17th Street and Castro]] |stations = 32 |daily_ridership = 23,208 (2013){{cite web |url=http://www.sfmta.com/node/97906#overlay-context=node/97906 |title=TEP Route Data & Proposed Changes |publisher=[[San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency]] (SFMTA) |year=2013 |accessdate=2014-04-08}} |open = 1983–1987 (Trolley Festivals)
{{start date and age|1995|9|1}} (revenue service) |owner = [[San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency]] |operator = [[San Francisco Municipal Railway]] |character = [[At-grade intersection|At grade]], [[street running]] |stock = '''[[San Francisco Municipal Railway fleet#Historic streetcars|Historic Muni streetcars]]:'''
1, 130, 162, 578
'''[[PCC streetcar]]s:'''
[[San Francisco Municipal Railway|Muni]], [[SEPTA]], [[New Jersey Transit|NJ Transit]]
'''Other historic streetcars:'''
[[New Orleans]], [[Blackpool]], [[Melbourne]], [[Milan]], [[Zurich]]
Additional unrestored streetcars |linelength = {{convert|6|mi|km|abbr=on}} |gauge = {{Track gauge|ussg|disp=or|allk=on}} |electrification = [[Overhead line]]s, 600 [[Volt|V]] [[Direct current|DC]] |elevation = At-grade, street-level |map = {{F Market & Wharves}}
[[File:FMarketMuni.png|center|250px|alt=F Market & Wharves map]] }} The '''F Market & Wharves''' line is one of several [[light rail]] lines in [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. Unlike most other lines in the system, the F line runs as a [[heritage streetcar]] service, almost exclusively using historic equipment both from San Francisco's retired fleet as well as from cities around the world (although busses are added during peak commute hours). While the F line is operated by the [[San Francisco Municipal Railway]] (Muni), its operation is supported by [[Market Street Railway (nonprofit)|Market Street Railway]], a nonprofit organization of [[Tram|streetcar]] enthusiasts which raises funds and helps to restore vintage streetcars. Despite its heritage status, the F Market & Wharves line is an integral part of Muni's intermodal urban transport network, operating at frequent intervals for 20 hours a day, seven days a week. It carries local commuters and tourists alike, linking residential, business and leisure oriented areas of the city. Unlike the [[San Francisco cable car system]], the cheaper standard Muni fare system applies. ==History== ===Previous F-Line=== {{Main article|F Stockton}} Cable car operations along Market Street began in 1888. Service was electrified 1906. In 1915, the [[San Francisco Municipal Railway]] started the F-Stockton route, which ran from Laguna (later Scott) and Chestnut Streets in the [[Marina District, San Francisco, California|Marina]] down Stockton Street to 4th and Market Streets near [[Union Square, San Francisco|Union Square]], later extended to the Southern Pacific Depot (currently the [[San Francisco 4th & King Street Station|Caltrain Depot]]) in 1947. The streetcar line was discontinued in 1951 and was replaced by the [[List of San Francisco Municipal Railway lines|30-Stockton]] route, which still runs today. The F-line designation was therefore available for use by the current line, although that service is over a completely different route from the F-line of 1915 to 1951. ===Previous lines on Market Street=== [[File:3 MUNI PCC Photos at Market St. near 2nd St. (26320435574).jpg|thumb|left|A PCC Streetcar on the K Ingleside route on Market Street in 1967]] [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market Street]] is a major transit artery for the city of San Francisco, and has carried in turn [[Horsecar|horse-drawn streetcars]], [[cable car (railway)|cable cars]] and electric [[tram|streetcars]]. In the 1960s construction began on the [[Market Street Subway]], which would carry [[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]]'s trains on its lower level. All streetcar lines currently operating in the subway previously ran on the surface of Market Street, and were eventually diverted into the upper level of the tunnel. This diversion, together with the provision of new [[light rail]] cars, resulted in today's [[Muni Metro]] system. The diversion of the Market Street streetcar lines into tunnel and the replacement of the existing streetcars with new light rail cars was completed by November 1982. However, the street trackage on Market Street was retained, and many of the old streetcars were still in storage. {{clear left}} ===Historic Trolley Festivals=== [[File:MUNI 130 at the Transbay Terminal in San Francisco, CA in October 1985 (32713992525).jpg|thumb|left|Streetcar #130 at the [[San Francisco Transbay Terminal|Transbay Terminal]] in 1985]] In 1982, [[San Francisco cable car system|San Francisco's cable car lines]] were shut down for almost two years to allow for a major rebuild. Temporary weekend historic streetcar service started on July 3, 1982 as part of 4th of July celebrations and ran until September of that year.{{Muni Chronology}} To provide a more regular alternative tourist attraction during this period, the San Francisco Historic Trolley Festivals began in 1983.{{cite book|last=Perles|first=Anthony|title=Tours of Discovery: A San Francisco Muni Album|year=1984|publisher=[[Interurban Press]]|isbn=0-916374-60-2|pages=136–142|chapter=Chapter 9: The Trolley Festival}} These summertime operations of vintage streetcars on Market Street were a joint project of the [[San Francisco Chamber of Commerce]] and Muni. The trolley festival route went from the [[Transbay Terminal]] at First and Mission Streets to Market, then up the retained Market Street tracks to Duboce Avenue. From there, it followed a 'temporary' streetcar detour built in the 1970s to bypass subway construction under Market: Duboce, Church Street, and [[Castro station|17th Street to Castro]]. {{clear left}} ===F-Market Line=== [[File:Muni 1053 at 17th and Castro, September 1999.jpg|thumb|left|Streetcar #1053 at 17th and Castro in 1999]] The Trolley Festival proved so successful it was repeated every year until 1987. In that year, preparation began for the introduction of a permanent F line. After that year’s festival finished, Muni replaced the old Market Street tracks with new ones, restoring tracks to upper Market Street and recreating a line to Castro. Different types of vintage streetcars were evaluated to provide the backbone of the F-line fleet, resulting in the decision to use the [[PCC streetcar|PCC car]], due in part to its historic San Francisco transit use. Fourteen such cars were acquired second-hand from [[Philadelphia]] to add to three of Muni’s own retired double-ended PCCs.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} On September 1, 1995, the F line opened[[Mac Sebree|Sebree, Mac]]. "Kodachrome PCCs Roll Down Market Street". ''[[Pacific RailNews]]'', November 1995 issue. [[Pentrex]].Ehrlich, Peter. "PCCs by the Bay". ''[[Passenger Train Journal]]'', June 1996 issue, pp. 24-31. [[Pentrex]]. with a parade of PCC cars, painted to represent some of the two dozen North American cities that this type of streetcar once served. Ridership exceeded expectations and the ''8-Market'' was finally completely discontinued on December 29, 1995. At that point in history, this was a rare instance in which a streetcar replaced a bus line in operation, rather than the other way around. The need for extra cars resulted in the acquisition of ten [[Peter Witt streetcar|Peter Witt style cars]] just being retired in the city of [[Milan]], Italy. These cars were built in the 1920s to a design once common in North American cities, and [[ATM Class 1500|their sister cars]] are still widely used on the [[Trams in Milan|Milan tramway network]]. {{clear left}} ===Extension on the Embarcadero=== [[File:San Francisco streetcar at Pier 39.jpg|thumb|left|An F Market & Wharves streetcar at Pier 39]] The [[Embarcadero, San Francisco|Embarcadero]] is the eastern waterfront roadway of San Francisco, along [[San Francisco Bay]]. At one time busy with port and ferry related traffic, it fell into decline as freight transferred to the [[container terminal]]s of [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] and the [[San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge|Bay Bridge]] replaced the ferries. In the 1960s the elevated [[California State Route 480|Embarcadero Freeway]] was built above, dividing the city from the bay, but was condemned and demolished after the [[1989 Loma Prieta earthquake]]. Proposals for streetcar service along The Embarcadero were put forward as early as 1974,{{cite web | title = Historic Streetcars | url = http://www.sfmta.com/cms/mfleet/histcars.php | publisher = San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency | accessdate = 2011-02-08}} and historic streetcar service along The Embarcadero was first provided during the 1987 Trolley Festival, using existing [[San Francisco Belt Railroad|Belt Railroad]] tracks on The Embarcadero and towed diesel generators to provide power. With increasing development of the waterfront for leisure and tourist activities, and the existence of [[Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco, California|Fisherman's Wharf]] and [[Pier 39]] at its northern end, it was decided to rebuild the Embarcadero as a tree-lined [[boulevard]] complete with a streetcar reservation. The section north of Market Street was to be served by an extension of the F line. Tracks were extended on the northern end of Market to connect with the Embarcadero tracks. In March 2000, service on the F line began along the new extension to Fisherman's Wharf.{{cite web | publisher = Market Street Railway | url = http://www.streetcar.org/mim/streetcars/history/index.html | title = A brief history of the F-line | accessdate = March 20, 2006 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20061003013218/http://www.streetcar.org/mim/streetcars/history/index.html | archive-date = October 3, 2006}} A month later, Muni dedicated a car to [[Herb Caen]], the noted columnist for the [[San Francisco Chronicle]] perhaps most famous for coining the phrase ''Baghdad by the Bay'' to describe The City. The car, Streetcar No. 130, which was originally delivered in 1914, contains wood paneling and is decorated with many quotes from Caen.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Take-a-trip-with-Herb-Caen-who-lives-on-in-an-2607409.php |title=Take a trip with Herb Caen, who lives on in an F-Market streetcar |author=King, John |date=22 September 2005 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=30 June 2016}}{{cite press release |url=https://www.sfmta.com/sites/default/files/pressreleases/2014/Press%20Release--SFMTA%20Announces%20Details%20of%20Muni%20Heritage%20Weekend%2010.29.14.pdf |title=SFMTA Announces Details of Muni Heritage Weekend |author=Rose, Paul |date=29 October 2014 |publisher=San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency |accessdate=30 June 2016}} ==Stations== The trolleys operate continuously, reversing direction via loops at the ends of the line. Although the cars are able to utilize the tunnels, the F-line operates on the street level. Along Market Street, trolleys stop at street level above nearby [[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]] and [[Muni Metro]] stations located below street level. | * '''[[Castro Street Station|Castro Station]]''' (Muni Metro) * Muni local routes 24, 33, 35, 37 * Muni owl routes 24, L | * Main stop for the [[Castro District, San Francisco, California|Castro District]], as well as for the [[Eureka Valley, San Francisco, California|Eureka Valley]] community * Muni local route 33 operates close by on 18th Street |} Except for the height of certain platforms (mostly on the T Third Street line), F Market & Wharves line cars are fully compatible with the rest of the [[Muni Metro]] system. Indeed, the cars can be privately chartered and are operated all over the system. ==Car fleet== {{Further information|San Francisco Municipal Railway fleet}} Muni owns a large selection of equipment for use on the F line, although not all of them are in service at the same time. The car fleet includes four sub-fleets: [[PCC streetcar]]s, [[Peter Witt streetcar]]s, pre-PCC veteran streetcars from San Francisco, and a diverse collection of 10 streetcars and trams from various overseas operators.{{cite web | url = http://www.streetcar.org/mim/streetcars/fleet/index.html | title = The historic streetcars of the F-line fleet | publisher = Market Street Railway | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2007-05-14}} The line is principally operated by a mixture of the PCC and Peter Witt cars, although other more unusual or historic cars are often in service (including the 913 and 952, iconic streetcars named [[Desire Street|Desire]]). Although the modern Muni LRVs are not compatible with F-line service because the overhead line is not compatible with [[Pantograph (transport)|pantograph]] operation, [[US Standard Light Rail Vehicle|Boeing LRVs]] have operated down parts of Market Street one or more times.[http://rides.webshots.com/photo/1391076612073654120xSjWvi MUNI LRVs--1258 @ Market/Duboce] ===PCC fleet=== [[File:Three PCCs on Jefferson Street, October 2017.jpg|thumb|left|Three streetcars - original Muni #1010, ex-Newark #1073, and ex-SEPTA #1059 - on Jefferson Street]] A fleet of [[PCC streetcar]]s from San Francisco, [[SEPTA|Philadelphia]], and [[Newark City Subway|Newark]], built between 1946 and 1948, operate on the line. {{asof|August 2007}}, MUNI was operating 27 of these cars, restored to various states of service. Among the restored cars in service, three are original San Francisco double-ended PCC cars. Another 16 cars are single-ended cars acquired from [[SEPTA]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] in 1992 (which continues to operate another 18 cars today, retrofitted for ADA compliance), while the remaining 11 cars are single-ended cars acquired from [[New Jersey Transit]] in [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] in 2002. MUNI has another 30 unrestored PCC cars in long-term storage.{{cite web | title = The PCC: A streetcar named success | url = http://www.streetcar.org/mim/streetcars/fleet/pcc/index.html | publisher = Market Street Railway | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2007-10-14}} The unrestored cars include five additional San Francisco double-ended cars, 10 San Francisco single-ended cars, 12 single-ended cars acquired from St. Louis in 1957, two single-ended cars from Philadelphia, and two single-ended cars from [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]]. A further previously restored car from Philadelphia was written off after a traffic accident in 2003.{{cite web | title = F-line fleet operational status | url = http://www.streetcar.org/mim/streetcars/status/index.html | publisher = Market Street Railway | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2007-10-14}} Many of the restored cars are painted in the color schemes of prominent past and present PCC streetcar operators, including Muni itself and other transit systems. ===Peter Witt fleet=== [[File:AFreshlyPaintedMilanPeterWittTramInTwoToneGreenOnItsThirdWeekOfServiceOnTheFLine.jpg|thumb|right|Former [[ATM Class 1500|Milan Peter Witt]] car carrying the two-tone green color scheme used by Milan in the 1930s.]] Muni operates a fleet of [[Peter Witt streetcar]]s on the line, acquired from [[Milan]], Italy. There are 11 of these cars, all built in 1928 to an Italian derivative of a common streetcar design that operated in many US cities, although never previously in San Francisco.{{cite web | title = The Milan 'Peter Witt' trams | url = http://www.streetcar.org/mim/streetcars/fleet/milan/index.html | publisher = Market Street Railway | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2007-10-14}} Most of San Francisco's Peter Witt cars are currently painted in the overall orange color scheme that they carried in Milan, although one has been repainted into its original livery of yellow and white with black trim, while another is in the two-tone green livery that the cars carried from the 1930s to the 1970s. ===San Francisco vintage fleet=== [[File:San Francisco 130 at foot of Market.jpg|thumb|left|Veteran San Francisco streetcar 130 was built for Muni in 1914, and operates in the livery it carried in 1939.]] The F-Line fleet also includes a fleet of pre-PCC vintage cars built between 1895 and 1924 for use in San Francisco. Three passenger cars were built for Muni itself, and a further two for the independent [[Market Street Railway Company]] that ran competing streetcar services in San Francisco until acquired by Muni in 1944. The final car is a works flat car, built for Muni in 1916 and used for hauling rails, ties, and other materials needed to maintain a streetcar system.{{cite web | title = Muni's incomparable antique streetcars | url = http://www.streetcar.org/mim/streetcars/fleet/antique/index.html | publisher = Market Street Railway | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2007-10-14}} The cars carry a variety of former San Francisco streetcar color schemes. ===Worldwide fleet=== [[File:233 boat tram! -muniheritage (21734580135).jpg|thumb|right|"Boat car" #233 from Blackpool]] The Muni's international fleet on the F-Line includes a diverse collection of 10 cars from various operators worldwide: * [[Blackpool tramway]], in [[Blackpool]], [[England]] (including two distinctive open-air [[Blackpool tramway#Boat cars|boat cars]]) * The former [[Trams in Hamburg|Hamburg tram system]], in [[Hamburg]], [[Germany]] * [[Hankai Tramway]], in [[Osaka]], [[Japan]] * [[Kobe Municipal Transportation Bureau]] & [[Hiroshima Electric Railway]], in [[Kobe]] & [[Hiroshima]], [[Japan]] * [[Trams in Melbourne|Melbourne & Metropolitan Tramways Board]], in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] * [[Trams in Moscow|Moscow tram system]], in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] ({{Track gauge|5ft|lk=on|disp=or}} system) * [[Trams in Porto|Porto tram system]], in [[Porto]], [[Portugal]] * [[Brussels trams|STIB/MIVB]], in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]]. All the cars carry the color schemes of their original operators, except for the Brussels car, which currently carries a color scheme paying tribute to San Francisco's twin city of [[Zürich]] in [[Switzerland]] (the streetcars actually in use in Zürich use meter-gauge and therefore cannot be moved to San Francisco). The Moscow trams had to be equipped with {{Track gauge|4ft8.5in}} [[Bogie|trucks]].{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} {{clear}} ==Fort Mason== [[File:West portal of Fort Mason Tunnel, June 2017.JPG|thumb|The abandoned railway tunnel under Fort Mason would be part of a planned extension]] Muni completed a technical feasibility study to extend the F-Line from the vicinity of the existing Jones Street terminal with the assistance of the National Park Service in December 2004. The extended line would extend westward alongside the [[San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park|San Francisco Maritime Museum and Aquatic Park]] and then through the historic (1914) but disused single-track [[Fort Mason Tunnel]], formerly owned by the [[San Francisco Belt Railroad|State Belt Railroad]]. An Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the extension, again led by the National Park Service, commenced in May 2006,{{cite web |url=https://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/management/extension-of-f-line-streetcar-service-to-fort-mason-center.htm |title=Extension of F-Line Streetcar Service to Fort Mason Center |author= |date=15 March 2013 |website=National Park Service |accessdate=30 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150307191008/http://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/management/extension-of-f-line-streetcar-service-to-fort-mason-center.htm |archivedate=7 March 2015 |deadurl=no}} resulting in: * a draft conceptual engineering report, issued in January 2009{{cite report |url=https://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/management/upload/NPS-HSC-Conceptual-Engineering-Report-Draft-2009-01-22-small3.pdf |title=DRAFT Conceptual Engineering Report |author=URS Corporation |date=22 January 2009 |publisher=National Park Service - Golden Gate National Recreation Area |accessdate=30 June 2016 |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl=no}} * a proposed transit operations plan, issued in July 2009{{cite report |url=https://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/management/upload/Final-Transit-Ops_2009-07-30_to-NPS-small3.pdf |title=FINAL Task 10 Working Paper: Transit Operations Plan |author=URS Corporation |date=July 2009 |publisher=National Park Service - Golden Gate National Recreation Area |accessdate=30 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630192151/https://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/management/upload/Final-Transit-Ops_2009-07-30_to-NPS-small3.pdf |archivedate=30 June 2016 |deadurl=no}} * a draft EIS, issued in March 2011{{cite press release |url=https://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/news/2011-0318.htm |title=Draft Environmental Impact Statement for Extension of F-Line Streetcar Service to Fort Mason Center Now Open for Comment |author1=Picavet, Alexandra |author2=Cullivan, Lynn |date=18 March 2011 |publisher=National Park Service |location=San Francisco, California |accessdate=30 June 2016}} * the Final EIS, issued in February 2012{{cite report |url=https://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/management/upload/PEPC_1_cvr_thru_ch2.pdf |title=Final Environmental Impact Statement for Extension of F-Line Streetcar Service to Fort Mason Center |author= |date=February 2012 |accessdate=30 June 2016 |publisher=Golden Gate National Recreation Area: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630191730/https://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/management/upload/PEPC_1_cvr_thru_ch2.pdf |archivedate=30 June 2016 |deadurl=no}} The final document classified areas west of the Fort Mason Tunnel as having "inadequate regional transit access...limited transportation options for transit-dependent residents...[and] infrastructure constraints impacting effectiveness and operations of Fort Mason Center." The Final EIS named a double-tracked extension along Beach Street, a jog north to Aquatic Park, then across Van Ness Avenue to single-tracked service through a retrofitted Fort Mason Tunnel and to a terminus in the Fort Mason Center parking lot as the "preferred alternative". ===Fort Mason extension stations=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;" |- ! style="width:15%;"|Stop !! style="width:10%;"|Outbound
(to Castro District) !! style="width:10%;"|Inbound
(to Fort Mason) !! style="width:9%;"|{{Access icon}} !! style="width:28%;"|Connections !! style="width:28%;"|Notes |- | ''[[Fort Mason]]''

{{about|the 1931 building at 570 Lexington Avenue|the 1933 building formerly named the GE Building|30 Rockefeller Plaza||General Electric Building (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = General Electric Building | nrhp_type = nrhp | image = General Electric Building 570 Lexington.jpg | caption = with [[St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, New York|St. Bartholomew's Church]] in the foreground (2010) | location= 570 [[Lexington Avenue (Manhattan)|Lexington Avenue]]
[[Manhattan]], [[New York City]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|45|26|N|73|58|20|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = United States Manhattan#New York City | built = 1929-31 | architect = John W. Cross of [[Cross & Cross]] | architecture = [[Art Deco]] | added = January 28, 2004 | governing_body = private | refnum = 03001515{{NRISref|2009a}} | designated_other2_name = NYC Landmark | designated_other2_date = July 9, 1985 | designated_other2_abbr = NYCL | designated_other2_link = New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission | designated_other2_number = | designated_other2_color = #ffe978 }} The '''General Electric Building''', also known as '''570 Lexington Avenue''', is a historic 50-floor, {{Convert|640|ft|m||adj=on}}-tall, skyscraper in [[Midtown Manhattan]], [[New York City]], at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and [[51st Street (Manhattan)|51st Street]]).{{cite web |title=570 Lexington Avenue |url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=570lexingtonavenuenue-newyorkcity-ny-usa |publisher=Emporis.com |accessdate=2008-07-12}} Originally known as the '''RCA Victor Building''' when designed in 1931 by John W. Cross of [[Cross & Cross]], it is sometimes known by its address to avoid confusion with the much later renaming – in 1988 – of the RCA Building at [[30 Rockefeller Plaza]] as the "GE Building", itself later renamed the "Comcast Building". The building was designated a [[New York City landmark]] in 1985,{{cite nycland}}, p.119 and was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on January 28, 2004.{{Cite web|url=http://architecturaltrust.org/~architec/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/2010_0617_respondent_motion_partial_summary_judgment.pdf|title=Tower 570 Company, L.P., Broadwell Investing Corp., Tax Matters Partner v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue|last=|first=|date=July 17, 2010|website=architecturaltrust.org|publisher=Internal Revenue Service|page=2|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 6, 2018}} ==History== At the time that [[RCA Victor]] commissioned this building, it was a subsidiary of [[General Electric]]. The company then moved its headquarters to Rockefeller Center, and this building was deeded over to the parent company. The building was donated to [[Columbia University]] in 1993 to gain a $40 million tax deduction.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/03/nyregion/ge-gives-midtown-tower-to-columbia-university.html|title=G.E. Gives Midtown Tower To Columbia University|last=Dunlap|first=David W.|date=June 3, 1993|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 6, 2018|language=en}} The university formed a joint venture with Mendik Company and Quantum Realty Partners and refurbished the building in 1994.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/15/realestate/streetscapes-570-lexington-avenue-columbia-s-restoring-an-art-deco-masterpiece.html|title=Streetscapes/570 Lexington Avenue; Columbia's Restoring an Art Deco Masterpiece|last=Gray|first=Christopher|date=January 15, 1995|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 6, 2018|language=en}} Mendik bought out Columbia in 2001.{{Cite web|url=http://www.wikicu.com/General_Electric_Building|title=General Electric Building - WikiCU, the Columbia University wiki encyclopedia|website=www.wikicu.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-18}} Tower 570 Company, LP, an affiliate of the Feil Organization, is the buildings current owner.{{Cite news|url=https://therealdeal.com/new-research/topics/property/570-lexington-avenue/|title=570 Lexington Avenue|work=The Real Deal New York|access-date=2017-11-18|language=en-US}} ==Architecture== The building's 50-floor stylized [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic]] octagonal brick tower, with elaborate [[Art Deco]] decorations of lightning bolts showing the power of electricity, grows out of the round-cornered base with elaborate masonry and architectural figural sculpture, to form "one of the most expressive skyscrapers of its era." The building was designed to blend with the low Byzantine dome of [[St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, New York|St. Bartholomew's Church]] on [[Park Avenue (Manhattan)|Park Avenue]] and shares the same brick color, with [[terra cotta]] decorations chosen to coordinate. The crown of the building is an example of Gothic [[tracery]], which is intended to represent electricity and radio waves, and is lit from within at night. On the corner above the building's main entrance is a clock with the cursive GE logo and a pair of disembodied silver arms holding bolts of electricity. The ''[[AIA Guide to New York City]]'' says that the building's "Art Deco details at both street and sky are both sumptuous and exuberant."{{cite aia5}}, p.318 A "major example" of Art Deco architecture, the style is "both symbolic and expressive of the building's function," according to the [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]].Savage, Charles C. (July 9, 1985) [http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/lp/1412.pdf "General Electric Building Designation Report"] [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] After the building was donated to Columbia University, it was extensively renovated by Ernest de Castro of the WCA Design Group. ==In popular culture== *When General Electric was in the process of purchasing RCA, [[David Letterman]], then host of NBC's [[Late Night with David Letterman]], brought a camera crew and a fruit basket to the building in an attempt to welcome their new corporate parents. They were greeted at the lobby by a GE official who demanded they stop filming and leave the premises, before placing his hand over the camera lens. *The General Electric Building was featured in the 2005 film ''[[Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005 film)|Mr. & Mrs. Smith]]'' as the location of the head office of Jane Doe ([[Angelina Jolie]]). *In the [[Netflix]] TV series ''[[Iron Fist (TV series)|Iron Fist]]'' set in the [[Marvel Comics|Marvel cinematic universe]], the character Harold Meachum lives in the penthouse of the General Electric Building. The series shows views of the lobby and exterior. ==Gallery== File:General Electric Building entry detail.jpg|The "GE" clock above the main entrance (2005) File:570 Lexington Avenue2.JPG|The crown of the building with its "electric waves" design (2013) File:General Electric Building 570 Lexington Avenue freight entrance on East 51st Street.jpg|Decoration over the freight entrance on 51st Street (2017) File:570 Lexington Ave- Lobby details.JPG|Part of the building's lobby (2015) File:A Deco Masterpiece.jpg|Another part of the lobby (2015) File:570 Lexington Ave- Lobby Ceiling.JPG|The lobby's ceiling (2015) ==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in New York City]] *[[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Manhattan from 14th to 59th Streets]] *[[List of National Historic Landmarks in New York City]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist}} '''Further reading''' *Stichweh, Dirk (2009) ''New York Skyscrapers''. Munich: Prestel Publishing. {{ISBN|3-7913-4054-9}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|General Electric Building (New York City)}} *[http://www.thecityreview.com/lex570.html History of the building] ''The City Review'' *[http://www.in-arch.net/NYC/nyc2a.html#33 The General Electric Tower] ''In-Arch Net'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050824214235/http://www.emporis.com/en/il/pc/?id=115512&aid=8 Photos] ''[[Emporis]]'' {{National Register of Historic Places in New York}} {{New York City Historic Sites}} {{General Electric}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1931]] [[Category:Art Deco architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Buildings and structures on the National Register of Historic Places in Manhattan]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Gábor Kovács | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1957|1|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Orosháza]], {{country|Hungary}} | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Hungarians|Hungarian]] | occupation = financier, banker, art collector, philanthropist | alma_mater = [[MGIMO]] | years_active = 1980– | boards = | website = [http://www.gaborkovacsartcollection.com/ Official homepage] | religion = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | signature = | signature_size = }}
'''Gábor Kovács''' (born 2 January 1957 in [[Orosháza]]) is a [[Hungarians|Hungarian]] financier, banker, art collector, philanthropist and founder of [[KOGART]].
== Life and career == Having studied at the Moscow State Institution for International Relations ([[MGIMO]]) between 1975 and 1980, he started his career at the [[Hungarian National Bank]]. He was the first managing director of Citibank Budapest from 1985, before becoming the vice-president of Citibank London. Back in Hungary by 1991, he founded Bankár Holding Plc., which he now heads as president and CEO. It was at this time that he began to collect works by, as well as to support, Hungarian artists. His collection spans the history of Hungarian painting from the early 18th to the mid-20th century.
On 8 November 2003, he established the Gábor Kovács Art Foundation with a HUF 3 bn capital stock, and opened KOGART House on 20 April 2004.
He has been a member of the Trilateral Commission since 2006.
Following its full-scale renovation, he reopened, with a new function, the Pauline-Carmelite Monastery of Sopronbánfalva in 2010, which was managed and owned by him till 2015 <ref name="A Monastery on the Frontier" />
Above all, he is interested in finding answers for the new social and economic challenges of the 21st century.
=== Milestones of his career === * 1980–1985 [[Hungarian National Bank]], Foreign Exchange Controls Department, International Section, Scandinavian officer, * 1985–1989 [[Citibank]] Rt. ([[Budapest]]), managing director, * 1989–1991 [[Citibank]] ([[London]]), vice-president, * 1991– Bankár Ltd. ([[Budapest]]), managing director, later Bankár Holding Plc., president-CEO.
=== ''Beauty—Harmony—Equilibrium'' === {{Quotation|align=center|"I learnt my sensitivity to beauty from my mother. As a child, I was already intrigued by man and landscape: beauty and harmony, the sense of space and the horizon, the meeting of the sky and the earth. Of course, I had no idea of such abstract notions in Kakasszék. All I knew was that people there were sincere and earned their living with hard work. Beauty is of course subjective. A face, a tree, a train arriving at the Kakasszék station, a lake nearby were beautiful. The larks starting to sing in spring and the return of the swallows showed the harmony of life. The birds gathering in autumn before migration hinted at transitoriness. Kakasszék is the past. It has changed. It has lost its character. Most of the elderly have left for other beauties. My mother moved closer to me. The feelings, however, are the same. This emotional world echoes in my collection, in this book.
In my early youth I was not too receptive to art. I was over thirty when it touched me. Since then I have been its captive. In 1991, for the empty walls of my new office I bought eight pictures, only Hungarian ones. The first sampling proved successful. Works by [[István Csók]], Gusztáv Magyar Mannheimer and Márk Rubovics are still noted items in my collection. Collecting became a passion and stole into my everyday life. My scope of interest kept stretching toward 19th-century classicist, romantic landscapes, then early 19th-century portraits, and I got to Nagybánya as well. The legacy of [[Ádám Mányoki]] and János Kupeczky is also part of the Hungarian atmosphere. The [[Hungarian National Gallery]] wanted Ferenc Rákóczi II to re-marry Charlotte Amelie, princess of Hessen. With my help, they managed to do so—for the duration of the Ádám Mányoki exhibition.
Lajos Gulácsy and [[Tivadar Kosztka Csontváry|Tivadar Csontváry Kosztka]] found me, too! By some miracle, masterpieces find me.
The encounter with the paintings of [[Károly Markó the Elder]] had an elementary impact on me. I was wholly overcome by the passion for Markó. György Károlyi commissioned Károly Markó the Elder to paint a picture in 1836. It was Women by the Well (Serpent Killer). The picture was owned by the Károlyi family during the past 150 years and it came into my possession by the courtesy of the heirs of Katinka Andrássy. It was an incredible accident again that I came across another latent chef d'œuvre known only in verbal description: St. Paul Shipwrecked on Malta. One Markó picture attracted the next. I bought the sixteenth item of my Markó collection at a Sotheby's auction in London in the summer of 2003. Another masterpiece—the painting had never been seen in Hungary. It was purchased by a Spanish infante after Markó's death in Italy, in the 1860s. I take greatest pride in this segment of my collection: the romantic landscapes, the Markós, Ligetis, Telepys. I probably owe it to this encounter that now I have not only some three hundred pictures but also a collection spunning from the early 18th century to 1935 expressing more or less the same sensitivity.
When it comes to the second half of the 20th century, however, I am at a loss. It was just a few years ago that I began to open up to this period. The works of art grow in number—[[Jenő Barcsay]], Menyhért Tóth, [[Endre Bálint]] and the lifework of János Bozsó, just to mention a few names. This material has not matured into a coherent whole yet. That will be my collector's task for the next ten years. The organizing principles are binding: sincerity, beauty, harmony... Works of art that are close to me, that touch me.
The past thirteen years of my life was about business in the first place and collecting art was only secondary. Giving up my post in London, I went into entrepreneurship. I wanted to show my expertise in my country. There were many transactions, many successes, my fortune increased. I kept rushing on, to new challenges, to new transactions. I did not realize the enormous difference between wealth and eternal values. I thought I would succeed in achieving everything. I was wrong.
After three years of bitter struggle, one day in 2002 I caught sight of Zsuzsa Péreli's latest work, Aequilibrium, on the wall of the Gobelin Museum in Aubusson. I immediately knew where I had made a mistake. It took just a nick of time to realize that the missing element in my successful but lopsided life was equilibrium. I had to create harmony not only in my environment, among the Markós, but also in my own soul. I realised that genuine equilibrium was not horizontal but between spiritual goals and earthly values. Between "Heaven" and "Earth". Earthly goals in heavenly perspectives. From the horizon of Kakasszék through the beauty of Markó's landscape I arrived at Péreli's search for equilibrium. I wish that everyone will cover this road in their hearts.
These experiences gave impetus to the idea of the [[Gábor Kovács Art Foundation]]. The 21st century is the century of foundations. Foundation is the future. The art works being created now will enrich the collection of the Gábor Kovács Art Foundation. We would like to build a collection characterized by beauty, harmony, a search for equilibrium, by inspired sincerity representing high spiritual goals and eternal values hidden in external beauty. I am sure that in the next one hundred years we will find the artists who "come in touch with God" as Csontváry says in his diary. After sixty years of solitude, our art will be part of European art again. And to the joy of us all, a collection will be created involving real values which have a message for us all."|Gábor Kovács, 2004<ref name="The Gábor Kovács Collection" />}}
== Awards and distinctions == 2005: Summa Artium Award, “For Contemporary Art” category, for his extensive work as an organizer and supporter of art. 2005: Knight’s Cross of the [[Order of Merit of the Republic of Hungary]]
== References == {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="A Monastery on the Frontier">A Monastery on the Frontier http://meonline.hu/en/archivum/kolostor-a-hataron</ref> <ref name="The Gábor Kovács Collection">''A Kovács Gábor-gyűjtemény / The Gábor Kovács Collection.'' Ed.: Fertőszögi, Péter – Kratochwill, Mimi. Vince Kiadó, Budapest, 2004. pp. 12-14.</ref> }}
== Sources == * Biográf Ki Kicsoda (Hungarian Who is Who). Budapest, 2002.
== External links == * [http://kogart.hu/kogart/en/founder_content.jsp About the founder] * [http://www.museum.hu/museum/temporary_en.php?IDT=8703&ID=236 Masterpieces of Hungarian Painting Art from the Selection of Gábor Kovács] * [http://www.banfalvakolostor.hu/en/history-3/monostery-history/ Monastery History 2004, 2009-2010] * [http://www.gaborkovacsartcollection.com Gábor Kovács Art Collection]
{{Authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox MP |honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] |name = Harry Atmore |honorific-suffix = |image = Harry Atmore, 1911.jpg |caption = |order1 = 19th [[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]] |term_start1 = 10 December 1928 |term_end1 = 22 September 1931 |predecessor1 = [[Robert Alexander Wright]] |successor1 = [[Robert Masters]] |primeminister1 = [[Joseph Ward]] |constituency_MP2 = [[Nelson (New Zealand electorate)|Nelson]] |parliament2 = New Zealand |term_start2 = 19 December 1911 |term_end2 = 11 December 1914 |predecessor2 = [[John Graham (New Zealand politician)|John Graham]] |successor2 = [[Thomas Field (politician)|Thomas Field]] |term_start3 = 17 December 1919 |term_end3 = 20 August 1946 |predecessor3 = Thomas Field |successor3 = [[Edgar Neale]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1870|12|14|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]], New Zealand |death_date = {{Death date and age|1946|08|20|1870|12|14|df=y}} |death_place = Nelson, New Zealand |party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] |otherparty = |spouse = {{marriage|Dorothy Annie Corrigan|1936}} |relations = |children = |occupation = |profession = Signwriter |religion = |signature = }} '''Harry Atmore''' (14 December 1870 – 20 August 1946) was a New Zealand [[Independent politician|Independent]] [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Nelson (New Zealand electorate)|Nelson]] in the [[South Island]]. Harry Atmore held the Nelson seat as an Independent for a total of thirty years from 1911 to 1914 and then from 1919 to his death in 1946. He was [[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]] and Minister in charge of the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research (DSIR) in Sir [[Joseph Ward]]'s [[United Government of New Zealand|United]] Government of 1928 to 1931, and the acting [[Prime Minister of New Zealand]] for approximately five months between 25 August 1930 and 21 January 1931. ==Early years== Born in [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]], in 1870, Atmore attended the Nelson Public School and represented the province in [[Rugby union|rugby]].{{DNZB|Tunnicliff|Shirley |4a23|Atmore, Harry|3 July 2011}} He later moved to [[Wellington]] and spent eight years there as an apprentice signwriter and decorator. After his apprenticeship, Atmore returned to Nelson and established his own signwriting and decorating business. Atmore was prominent in local affairs. He was a member of the Nelson Licensing Committee, Education Board and Hospital Board. In 1905, he was elected to the [[Nelson City Council]]. Later, he served on the [[Nelson College]] Council of Governors and [[Cawthron Institute]] Trust Board. ==Member of Parliament== {{NZ parlbox header|nolist=true|align=left}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1911}}|end=14|term=18th|electorate={{NZ electorate link|Nelson}}|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox break}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1919}}|end=22|term=20th|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1922}}|end=25|term=21st|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1925}}|end=28|term=22nd|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1928}}|end=31|term=23rd|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1931}}|end=35|term=24th|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1935}}|end=38|term=25th|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1938}}|end=43|term=26th|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{NZ parlbox|start={{NZ election link year|1943}}|end=46|term=27th|electorate=Nelson|party=Independent politician}} {{end}} Atmore unsuccessfully contested the Nelson seat in 1902, 1905 and 1908 against the [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal]] [[John Graham (New Zealand politician)|John Graham]]. In 1911 he became Nelson's Member of Parliament. Atmore gave his support in [[Joseph Ward]]'s Liberal government by voting for it on a no-confidence motion, which was saved by just one vote. Whilst remaining an independent, he normally supported the Liberals from then on. Regardless, Atmore's political independence was always discernible. He believed that politicians should be, first and foremost, representatives of the people. That when elected they should put principle before party. Atmore lost his seat in the 1914 election, but returned to parliament in 1919 after unsuccessfully contesting the Wellington Central {{By-election link|Wellington Central|1918}} which was won by [[Peter Fraser (New Zealand politician)|Peter Fraser]], the [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] candidate.{{cite news|title=A victory for Labour |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19181004.2.11.1 |work=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=XCVI |issue=83 |date=4 October 1918 |page=3 |accessdate=15 March 2014}} Initially, Atmore was opposed to the rising Labour Party and was doubtful of its socialist agenda. He was also an admirer of [[Benito Mussolini]] due to his opposition to socialist radicals in Italy. As a result, Labour put considerable effort in to defeat him in 1925. Gradually Atmore's animosity towards Labour lessened and Labour did not stand a candidate against him after that. Following the 1928 election he supported Ward's new United Party form a majority and was rewarded with a position in cabinet, as [[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]]. As a largely self-educated man, he had passionate concern for education and took to his new responsibilities with vigor. Atmore's first goal as education minister was to ensure every child in New Zealand could have the opportunity to gain a proper education to realise their own potential. He formed a committee to examine the existing public education system. The outcome was the "[[The Atmore Report, 1930|Atmore Report]]" which recommended several radical reforms including raising the age to leave school to 15, establishing intermediate schools, abolishing scholarship entry to secondary school, and widening the secondary school curriculum to also cover non University approved subjects. [[File:United Cabinet, 1928.jpg|thumb|250px|Atmore (seated first on left) in the United cabinet, 1928.]] Atmore resigned as education minister in 1931 when cuts were proposed for his portfolio due to the worsening depression and formation of the [[United–Reform coalition Government of New Zealand|coalition government]] which he was opposed to.{{Cite report |last=Courtney |first=S D |year=n.d. |title=Harry Atmore: Independent in Politics |publisher=[[University of Canterbury]] |page=21}} However, many of his ideas were later implemented under the [[First Labour Government of New Zealand|First Labour Government]] where Peter Fraser (who was a member of Atmore's Committee) was minister of education. Fraser's Education Amendment Act 1938 was to endorse and implement most of Atmore's recommendations. Atmore read and thought widely. He was one New Zealander who was looking for solutions to problems within the altered economic, social and political context of inter-war New Zealand. He believed it was important to be informed on the issues of the day including monetary reform, international rearmament and the pivotal role of the [[USSR]] in any crisis. Curiously, he was a [[social credit]] monetary reform sponsor and campaigned for it vigorously, blaming many of New Zealand's debt problems in the early 1930s on obligations to pay interest on its debts in London. On 8 August 1946 Atmore announced his intention not to stand again at the next election. However, only two weeks later, on 20 August, he was found dead at his home. He was buried at [[Wakapuaka Cemetery]].{{cite web |url=http://information.ncc.govt.nz/cgi-bin/cemetery/ceppncc?key=WKNG19075 |title=Cemeteries database |date= |website= |publisher=Nelson City Council |accessdate=29 September 2014}} ==Personal life== Atmore was a well known man in Nelson, refusing to drive a car, instead preferring to ride a bicycle everywhere locally which made him a visible addition to the community. He personally answered all messages and requests in his own handwriting as an indication of his dedication to his work. Atmore married Dorothy Annie Corrigan on 24 June 1936, at the age of 65, at Hawera. There were no children from the marriage. Dorothy was both wealthy and well-educated. The two built a new home named Te Maunga and made it a local centre of hospitality. Throughout [[World War II]] the two were both actively involved in patriotic work, which was to earn Dorothy an MBE. Dorothy lived a further thirty years as a widow, dying in 1976. Atmore's grip on the Nelson seat was due primarily to his commitment and availability to his constituents. He organised a call to repair a country school, the completion of the Nelson railway, an exemption for an only son of an elderly farming couple from military service and helped issue jobs in the public service to the unemployed. For an entire generation Atmore worked for all Nelson residents with such a commitment that his constituents regarded him to be a personal friend. ==Legacy== [[File:Harry Atmore.jpg|thumb|Atmore, late 1920's.]] In 1935, he was awarded the [[King George V Silver Jubilee Medal]].{{cite news | url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19350506.2.12 | title=Official jubilee medals | date=6 May 1935 |volume=CXIX |issue=105 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] | accessdate=2 July 2013 | page=4 }} Robert Chapman comments on Harry Atmore:''New Zealand Politics in Action: The 1960 General Election'' by R M Chapman, W K Jackson and A V Mitchell p213 (1962, Oxford University Press, London) :Nelson even shares with [[Hobson (NZ electorate)|Hobson]] a record of preferring political idiosyncrancy. Nine times out of ten between 1911 and 1946 Nelson voted for Harry Atmore, who confounded cynics by moving to the Left politically as he got older. Having begun as an [[Independent Liberal]], he thereafter passed through many shades of independence to finish as his own variety of consistently pro-Labour MP. Historians have regarded Atmore as the last example of an earlier, simpler political age, before the rise of the party system. He embodied the aspirations of small town residents and their desires for a fairer and more egalitarian society. ==Books== *"This Debt Slavery" by Harry Atmore, M.P. and [[John A. Lee]], M.P. (1940 Budget Speeches, Commercial Printing & Publishing, Auckland). *"The Mortgage Corporation Bill" by Harry Atmore, M.P. and [[Harold Rushworth|Capt. Harold Rushworth]], M.P. (A copy is held at the Macmillan Brown Library, University of Canterbury, Christchurch). *"You and the USSR" by Harry Atmore, M.P. and 'Uncle Scrim' i.e. [[Colin Scrimgeour|Colin G. Scrimgeour]] (1941, Society for Closer Relations with Russia, Wellington). ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://thecommunityarchive.org.nz/node/71620/description Harry Atmore's Political Papers. National Register of Archives and Manuscripts] ==See also== *[[The Atmore Report, 1930]] {{s-start}} {{s-par | nz}} {{s-bef | before = [[John Graham (New Zealand politician)|John Graham]] }} {{s-ttl | rows = 2 | title = [[Nelson (New Zealand electorate)|Member of Parliament for Nelson]] | years = 1911–1914
1919–1946 }} {{s-aft | after = [[Thomas Field (politician)|Thomas Field]] }} {{s-bef | before = Thomas Field }} {{s-aft | after = [[Edgar Neale]] }} {{s-off}} {{s-bef | before = [[Robert Alexander Wright|Robert Wright]]}} {{s-ttl | title = [[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]] |years=1928–1931}} {{s-aft | after = [[Robert Masters]]}} {{end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Atmore, Harry}} [[Category:1870 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:Independent MPs of New Zealand]] [[Category:Members of the Cabinet of New Zealand]] [[Category:Nelson City Councillors]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Nelson, New Zealand]] [[Category:New Zealand education ministers]] [[Category:New Zealand MPs for South Island electorates]] [[Category:Members of the New Zealand House of Representatives]] [[Category:Burials at Wakapuaka Cemetery]] [[Category:Unsuccessful candidates in the New Zealand general election, 1902]] [[Category:Unsuccessful candidates in the New Zealand general election, 1905]] [[Category:Unsuccessful candidates in the New Zealand general election, 1908]] [[Category:Unsuccessful candidates in the New Zealand general election, 1914]] [[Category:People associated with the Cawthron Institute]] [[Category:New Zealand Freemasons]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Iman Mutlaq | image = File:Iman Mutlaq.jpg | alt = Iman Mutlaq | caption = Iman Mutlaq | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = {{flag|Kingdom of Saudi Arabia}} | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = {{flag|Jordan}}ian | residence = [[Amman]], Jordan. | other_names = | title = [[Sigma Investments Group]]
''[[CEO|Founder and CEO]]''
(Amman, Jordan)
Director of INGOT Consultation Bahrain
Director of Global Alliance Partners
''([[Hong Kong]])''
President at IAHV, Jordan
Founder of 8x8 Women, Jordan

''([[Jordan]] headquartered & [[Estonia]] registered)''

[[Financier]]
[[Humanitarian|Humanitarian worker]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | website = {{url|http://www.imanmutlaq.com}} }} '''Iman Mutlaq''' is a [[Jordan|Jordanian]] entrepreneur, financier and social activist. She is the founder of the [[Sigma Investments Group|Sigma Investments]] and INGOT Coin.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ingotcoin.io/#team|title=MEET OUR TEAM|accessdate=April 6, 2018|work=INGOT Coin| date=}} ==Early life== Mutlaq was born in [[Saudi Arabia]]. Following her father's death when she was six years old, she was raised by her mother. Though her family kept close company with Saudi royals, Mutlaq struggled to become involved in the typical [[Patriarchy|male-centric]] Arabian public life. She started to sell arts and crafts at school when she was 14 years old to support her education.{{Cite web|url= http://www.jordanbusinessmagazine.com/cover_story/jordan-business-unveils-10-most-powerful-jordanian-women|title=Jordan Business Unveils 10 Most Powerful Jordanian Women |accessdate=October 18, 2015|work= Jordan Business | date=August 2014}} ==Family== Mutlaq raised her two sons as a single mother, after her divorce at the age of twenty four. ==Education== Mutlaq received an MBA in Finance from the [[New York Institute of Technology]]. ==Career== Mutlaq established her export-import business at the age of eighteen and then entered in the financial industry at the age of 27 covering the regions of Middle East and North Africa. She is currently managing [[Jordan]] based Sigma Investments. She directs INGOT Consultation Bahrain which is a financial services provider since 2015 focuing [[MENA]] region; and enables trading on global currencies and precious metals, and also facilitates clients on reaching foreign exchange markets.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ft.lk/article/584932/INGOT-Brokers-introduces-services-in-Sri-Lanka-%C2%A0|title=INGOT Brokers introduces services in Sri Lanka |accessdate=August 5, 2018|work=[[Daily FT]]| date=9 December 2016}} She is involved in angel investment encouraging projects which enhance women's creativity and ideas. She is also targeting applications for mobile devices through her startup, "Dreamtech" since 2015. She is the founder of INGOT Coin, a [[Jordan]] headquartered and [[Estonia]] registered, decentralized [[cryptocurrency]] (since 2018), which has an integrated wallet with a [[digital bank]]{{Cite web|url=https://thecurrencyanalytics.com/2268/digital-bank-of-ingot-coin-providing-cryptocurrency-holders-with-round-the-clock-banking-services/|title=Digital Bank of INGOT Coin: Providing Cryptocurrency Holders with Round-the-Clock Banking Services |accessdate=August 19, 2018|work=[[The Currency Analytics]]|}} , brokerage service, crypto certifier, community and [[Initial coin offering|ICO]] accelerator. ==Activism and women's empowerment== [[File:Iman Mutlaq visits Zaatari Refugee Camp.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Iman visits the [[Zaatari refugee camp]] for implementing [[psychosocial]] support by the IAHV, Jordan; co-funded by the [[European Union]] for the [[Syrian refugees]].]] Participant in an expedition to Mount [[Kilimanjaro]] in 2014 in an effort to support the [[cancer research]] initiatives of the [[King Hussein Cancer Center]]; the expedition raised $1.3 million.{{Cite web|url=http://jordantimes.com/24-jordanians-to-climb-mount-kilimanjaro-to-support-cancer-centre|title=24 Jordanians to climb Mount Kilimanjaro to support cancer centre|accessdate=December 3, 2014|work=The Jordan Times|date=August 18, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220073649/http://jordantimes.com/24-jordanians-to-climb-mount-kilimanjaro-to-support-cancer-centre|archivedate=December 20, 2014|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.khcc.jo/news/king-hussein-cancer-foundation-and-center-announces-launch-new-initiative-climb-mount|title=King Hussein Cancer Foundation and Center Announces the Launch of a New Initiative to Climb Mount Kilimanjaro, the Roof of Africa|accessdate=December 3, 2014|work=King Hussein Cancer Foundation| date=August 18, 2013}} First instructor of the [[Art of Living Foundation]], an initiative of [[Sri Sri Ravi Shankar]] in Jordan. President of the [[Geneva]] headquartered International Association for Human Values(IAHV) in Jordan. Initiator of six programs in Iraq among 400 women for advancing their careers.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iahv.org.jo|title=The Advancing Career Women Project (ACWP)|accessdate=December 3, 2014|work=The International Association for Human Values| date=}} Participant at the inaugural [[US]] [[Presidential Summit on Entrepreneurship]] invited by [[Presidency of Barack Obama|The Obama Administration]] in 2010; she met [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[Richard Holbrooke]] there and discussed issues affecting women in Afghanistan and across the Middle East. ==Sigma Investments Group== {{main|Sigma Investments Group}} [[File:Iman Mutlaq with Khaled Hanafi.jpeg|thumb|250px|Iman signs cooperation protocol with Khaled Hanafi, Egypt's Supply Minister on behalf of the consortium to establish first ever electronic [[Egyptian Commodities Exchange]] in Egypt in November 2015.]] Sigma Investments and Ingot are members of the three member consortium which signed cooperation protocol with [[Egypt]]ian government to establish a US$35–50m worth electronic [[Egyptian Commodities Exchange]] in Egypt as the first ever country in the [[MENA]] region; it will facilitate the well being of the small farmers and supply of products at reasonable prices abolishing the monopoly of goods.{{Cite web|url= http://english.mubasher.info/news/2848324/Global-consortium-to-inject-50m-in-Egypt-commodity-exchange#.Vlm5qiJtFzg.facebook|title=Global consortium to inject $50m in Egypt commodity exchange|accessdate=November 28, 2015|work=MUBASHER| date=26 November 2015}}{{Cite web|url= http://thecairopost.youm7.com/news/179289/news/egypt-signs-protocol-to-establish-commodities-exchanges#prettyPhoto|title=Egypt signs protocol to establish commodities exchanges|accessdate=November 30, 2015|work=The Cairo Post| date=26 November 2015}} ==Achievements and awards== *[[Forbes]] magazine's [[Middle East]] edition, published in 2016, 2017 and 2018 ranked Iman Mutlaq to 32nd, 41st and 38th positions respectively in a list of "The 100 Most Powerful Arab Businesswomen."{{Cite web|url= http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/lists/read/2016/the-100-most-powerful-arab-businesswomen/listid/292|title=The 100 Most Powerful Arab Businesswomen|accessdate=September 27, 2016|work=[[Forbes]](Middle East)''| date=2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/list/top-100-powerful-arab-businesswomen-2017/item/41/ |title=The Top 100 Most Powerful Arab Businesswomen 2017|accessdate=July 19, 2017|work=[[Forbes]](Middle East)''| date=2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/list/the-middle-easts-most-influential-women-2018/item/38/|title=The Top 100 Most Powerful Arab Businesswomen 2018|accessdate=October 6, 2018|work=[[Forbes]](Middle East)''| date=2018}} *''Keynote Speaker'' at the first "Asia-Pacific Executives Forum" which was held at [[Hilton Hotels & Resorts|Hilton Hotel]] in [[Sri Lanka]] in 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://dailynews.lk/2017/12/07/business/136628/minister-dr-amunugama-chief-guest-first-asia-pacific-executives-forum|title=Minister Dr. Amunugama Chief Guest at First Asia-Pacific Executives Forum|accessdate=December 31, 2017|work= Lake House| date=December 7, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Asia-Pacific-Executives-Forum-held-at-Hilton-Colombo-142899.html|title=Asia-Pacific Executives Forum held at Hilton Colombo|accessdate=December 31, 2017|work=Wijeya Newspapers| date=December 7, 2017}} *''Best Woman in the Corporate Sector'' at the AmCham MENA Council Women in Business Awards in 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsofbahrain.com/viewNews.php?ppId=17354&pid=21&MNU= |title=AmCham Bahrain Women in Business Awards |accessdate=October 26, 2016|work= News of Bahrain| date=March 25, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://gulfnewsjournal.com/stories/510703943-women-take-center-stage-at-amcham-mena-council-women-in-business-awards |title= Women take center stage at AmCham MENA Council Women in Business Awards|accessdate=October 26, 2016|work= Gulf News Journal| date=March 27, 2016}} *''Global Alliance Partners'', a network of financial entities has elected Iman as the first female director at its Conference in New York City in 2016. * Jordan's Top Businesswomen in 2015. * Iman has been appointed "Goodwill Ambassador for Human Rights and Peace" in Jordan in 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://www.venturemagazine.me/2015/03/jordans-top-businesswomen-iman-mutlaq|title=Jordan’s Top Businesswomen: Iman Mutlaq|accessdate=October 21, 2015|work=Venture Magazine| date=March 9, 2015}} == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Iman Mutlaq}} * [https://thecurrencyanalytics.com/1740/ingot-brokers-announces-accepting-cryptocurrencies-as-a-method-of-payment/ Ingot Brokers announces accepting cryptocurrencies as a method of payment] * [http://www.imanmutlaq.com/en/news/press-lounge Press Lounge] * [http://www.venturemagazine.me/2015/03/jordans-top-businesswomen-iman-mutlaq/ Jordan’s Top Businesswomen: Iman Mutlaq] * [http://english.mubasher.info/news/2848324/Global-consortium-to-inject-50m-in-Egypt-commodity-exchange#.Vlm5qiJtFzg.facebook Global consortium to inject $50m in Egypt commodity exchange] * [https://www.reuters.com/article/egypt-commodities-exchange-idUSL8N15G2A2 Egypt to launch agricultural commodities bourse by year-end] ([[Reuters]]) * [http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/lists/people/pname/iman-mutlaq/pid/90398/ The 100 Most Powerful Arab Businesswomen] ([[Forbes]] Middle East) * [https://bitcoinexchangeguide.com/ingot-coin-trade-io-join-strategic-partnership-to-strengthen-ico/ INGOT Coin & Trade.io Join Strategic Partnership to Strengthen ICO] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mutlaq, Iman}}
