Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Infobox restaurant | name = The Halal Guys | image = 53rd and 6th.jpg | image_width = 300px | image_caption = Line at the cart (2007) | established = 1990 | current-owner = Mohamed Abouelenein | head-chef = | food-type = [[Halal]], [[Middle Eastern cuisine]] | dress-code = | rating = | street-address = Corners of 53rd St and [[Sixth Avenue|6th Avenue]] (main and second locations) | city = [[Manhattan]], New York City | state = New York | zip = 10019 | country = United States | coordinates = {{Coord|40.76180|N|73.97928|W |format=dms |type:landmark_region:US-NY_scale:1000 |display=inline,title}} | seating-capacity = | reservations = | other-locations = | other-information = | website = {{url|thehalalguys.com}} }}
'''The Halal Guys''' is a [[halal]] [[fast casual restaurant]] [[Franchising|franchise]] that began as a [[food cart]] on the south-east corner of [[53rd Street (Manhattan)|53rd Street]] and [[Sixth Avenue]] in the [[Boroughs of New York City|borough]] of [[Manhattan]] in New York City. The franchise also has a cart on the south-west corner of the same intersection. New locations, both food cart and storefront, are being added throughout New York (including a storefront on [[14th Street (Manhattan)|14th Street]] and [[Second Avenue (Manhattan)|Second Avenue]]) and around the world.
The [[Franchising|franchise]] is most recognized by its primary dish which is a platter of chicken or [[gyro (food)|gyro]] meat with rice,<ref name=home>{{cite web|url=http://www.53rdand6th.com/|title=We Are Different|website=53rdand6th.com|accessdate=March 4, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305133246/http://www.53rdand6th.com/#|archive-date=2009-03-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> though it also serves a chicken or gyro wrap sandwich.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://midtownlunch.com/blog/2007/05/03/ask-midtown-lunch-best-chicken-and-rice-cart/|title=Ask Midtown Lunch: Best Chicken and Rice Cart|publisher=Midtown Lunch|accessdate=March 4, 2009}}</ref><ref name=home/><ref name=DotD>{{cite news|author=Saki Knafo|date=July 29, 2007|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/29/nyregion/thecity/29hala.html?ref=thecity|title=Decline of the Dog|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=March 4, 2009}}</ref>
==History== The Halal Guys was founded in 1990 by Egyptian-descendent Mohamed Abouelenein,<ref name="Vadukul 2014">{{cite web | last=Vadukul | first=Alex | title=The Halal Guys: Cashing In on Street Cred |work=[[The New York Times]]| date=2014-06-15 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/15/nyregion/the-halal-guys-cashing-in-on-street-cred.html | access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> along with compatriots Ahmed Elsaka and Abdelbaset Elsayed, as a [[hot dog cart]] located on 53rd Street and Sixth Avenue.<ref name=DotD/><ref name=restaurant>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/eats/halal-guys-food-cart-open-restaurant-east-village-article-1.1474330|title=Halal Guys food cart to open restaurant in East Village|author=Carol Kuruvilla|date=2013-10-02|work=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=2014-02-25}}</ref> Abouelenein, however, believed that a hot dog was not a satisfying meal, and switched to the current menu of chicken, gyro meat, rice, and pita in 1992.<ref name=DotD/> As a result, New York City’s [[Muslim]] cab drivers flocked to the cart for its ability to provide a quick, relatively inexpensive halal meal. As word of the cart spread via these chatty cabbies, the now-famous platter of chicken and rice was born, and popularized within the Muslim community in the city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehalalguys.com/our-story/|title=Our Story {{!}} The Halal Guys|website=thehalalguys.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref>
The [[Food cart|cart]] has caused a decline in the popularity of hot dog vendors in New York City and has influenced many imitation carts.<ref name=DotD/> A cart called 'New York's Best Halal Food' is also located on 53rd Street and Sixth Avenue on the southwest corner. It is unknown which cart was located at the intersection first.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.seriouseats.com/2012/10/best-halal-cart-53rd-street-6th-avenue-street-food.html|title=Taste Test: The 53rd and 6th Halal Street Food Showdown|publisher=[[Serious Eats]]|author=Max Falkowitz|accessdate=2014-02-28}}</ref>
On October 28, 2006, a fight that started in line ended with 23-year-old Ziad Tayeh stabbing and killing 19-year-old Tyrone Gibbons.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jen Chung|url=http://www.gothamist.com/archives/2006/10/29/street_food_sta.php|title=Street Food Stabbing|publisher=[[Gothamist]]|date=2006-10-29|accessdate=2009-03-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201232209/http://www.gothamist.com/archives/2006/10/29/street_food_sta.php|archivedate=2008-12-01|df=}}</ref> Tayeh was later found not guilty, as the jury found that he acted in self-defense. The fight began after one accused the other of [[cutting in line]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Shayna Jacobs|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/whack-smack-article-1.1326492|title=Brooklyn man who beat 2009 murder rap for killing line cutter arrested for heroin possession|work=[[New York Daily News]]|date=2013-04-24|accessdate=2014-02-25}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' once reported that the owners had hired [[Bouncer (doorman)|bouncers]].<ref name=DotD/>
The Halal Guys donated $30,000 to [[LaGuardia Community College]] in 2016 with the money intended to fund scholarships for students experiencing financial hardships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/26/nyregion/halal-guys-to-donate-30000-to-laguardia-community-college.html|title=Halal Guys to Donate $30,000 to LaGuardia Community College|date=2016-05-25|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/TheHalalGuys/photos/a.433271123364423.103813.157700344254837/630316116993255/?type=1&theater|title=The Halal Guys|website=Facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref>
==Food== The Halal Guys serves "American [[halal]]" platters and sandwiches, prepared using ingredients such as chicken, gyro meat, [[falafel]] and rice.<ref name="McKibben 2017">{{cite web | last=McKibben | first=Beth | title=The Halal Guys Are Coming to Midtown Atlanta | website=Eater Atlanta | date=December 14, 2017 | url=https://atlanta.eater.com/2017/12/14/16776484/the-halal-guys-coming-to-midtown-atlanta-spring | access-date=December 28, 2017}}</ref> The taste has been described as entailing a complex melting pot of flavors originating from the Mediterranean and Middle East.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehalalguys.com/american-halal/|title=American Halal {{!}} The Halal Guys|website=thehalalguys.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref> The Halal Guys also serve a white sauce [[condiment]] which patrons cite as a favorite and has been described as "famous".<ref name="Carpenter 2017">{{cite web | last=Carpenter | first=Evie | title=The White Sauce at The Halal Guys is Magic, But Is Anything Else? | website=Phoenix New Times | date=February 7, 2017 | url=http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/restaurants/the-white-sauce-at-the-halal-guys-is-magic-but-is-anything-else-9060373 | access-date=December 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Metro US 2017">{{cite web | title=The Halal Guys is leading the restaurant industry in global domination | website=Metro US | date=August 3, 2017 | url=https://www.metro.us/news/local-news/new-york/nycs-halal-guys-leads-industry-global-domination | access-date=December 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Delgado 2017">{{cite web | last=Delgado | first=Lauren | title=First Bite: Halal Guys in east Orlando | website=Orlando Sentinel | date=August 30, 2017 | url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/food-restaurants/foodie-blog/os-et-halal-guys-20170830-story.html | access-date=December 28, 2017}}</ref> A "distant cousin of tzatziki", the Halal Guys' white sauce has been the subject of multiple recreations based on ingredients on to-go packets, but to no avail.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ny.eater.com/2014/12/24/7447241/halal-guys-white-sauce-ingredients-revealed|title=New To-Go Packets Reveal That Halal Guys' Top Secret White Sauce Is Basically Just Flavored Mayo|work=Eater NY|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thrillist.com/recipe/new-york/halal-white-sauce-thrillist-recipes|title=My Quest to Reverse Engineer The Halal Guys' White Sauce Recipe|last=Santanachote|first=Perry|date=2015-05-15|work=Thrillist|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kcet.org/how-the-halal-guys-made-it-from-new-yorks-streets-to-southern-california|title=How The Halal Guys Made it From New York's Streets to Southern California|date=2016-12-29|work=KCET|access-date=2018-05-20|language=en}}</ref> A similar condiment is found at all or most other halal carts in New York City, but the recipe likely often varies from cart to cart.<ref name="Krishna 2017">{{cite web | last=Krishna | first=Priya | title=How Street Meat Conquered New York | website=New York Magazine | date=October 1, 2017 | url=http://www.grubstreet.com/2017/11/halal-cart-chicken-and-rice-oral-history.html | access-date=December 28, 2017}}</ref> The Halal Guys also prepares a red hot sauce.<ref name="Carpenter 2017"/>
==Locations== [[File:The Halal Guys NYC.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|The Halal Guys food cart in New York City]] [[File:Chicken and beef gyro combo with fountain drink, The Halal Guys (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Franchise offering: chicken and beef gyro combo lunch with fountain drink (Springfield, Virginia)]] *The main cart is located on [[53rd Street (Manhattan)|53rd Street]] and [[Sixth Avenue|Sixth Avenue]] during weekday evenings (7pm–4am) and weekends, across from the [[New York Hilton Midtown|Hilton Hotel]] on the southwest corner. *A second cart is located across the street from the original cart, on the southeast corner of that intersection, and is open both during the daytime and at night.<ref>{{cite web|author=''Robin Raisfeld'' and ''Rob Patronite''|date=June 18, 2007|url=http://nymag.com/restaurants/features/33527/index3.html|title=The Concrete Elite New York’s twenty best food carts ranked in order|publisher=New York Restaurants|accessdate=2009-03-04}}</ref> *A third cart exists on the southwest corner of 53rd Street and [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|7th Avenue]], and begins serving food at lunch time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://midtownlunch.com/blog/2008/08/19/famous-halal-guys-cart-on-53rd-6th-adds-another-cart-on-7thchicken-and-lamb-over-rice-street-meat-nyc/|title=Famous Halal Cart on 53rd & 6th, Adds Another Cart on 7th|publisher=Midtown Lunch|accessdate=2009-03-04}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *In November 2013, the Halal Guys announced its intentions to open a restaurant located on [[14th Street (Manhattan)|14th Street]] and [[Second Avenue (Manhattan)|2nd Avenue]], according to general manager Hesham Hegazy.<ref name=restaurant/> *In December 2014, the Halal Guys opened a restaurant on [[Tenth Avenue (Manhattan)|Amsterdam Avenue]] and West [[95th Street (Manhattan)|95th Street]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westsiderag.com/2014/12/18/restaurant-openings-halal-guys-maharaja-voila-chocolat-sushi-spot|title=Restaurant Openings: Halal Guys, Maharaja, Voila Chocolat, Sushi Spot|publisher=Westside Rag|accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref> *The Halal Guys opened their first Chicago location on August 20, 2015. The restaurant is located in Chicago's [[Gold Coast Historic District (Chicago)|Gold Coast]] neighborhood. Four more locations are expected to open in the city.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chicago's First of Five Planned Halal Guys Opens Tonight in Gold Coast|url = http://chicago.eater.com/2015/8/20/9182065/halal-guys-opening-gold-coast-chicagos-first-of-five|website = Eater Chicago|accessdate = 2015-08-24}}</ref> *On October 2, 2015, the Halal Guys opened a restaurant in [[Costa Mesa, California]], the first location on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]]. The business plans to expand in [[Southern California]] with 50 franchised units sold already.<ref>{{cite web|author=''Benjamin Brown''|date=September 29, 2015|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/halal-685057-guys-food.html|title=New York food phenom Halal Guys to open first West Coast eatery in Costa Mesa|publisher=The Orange County Register|accessdate=2015-10-07}}</ref> *In October 2015, the Halal Guys opened up shop in Megamall Manila in the Philippines. More locations has been added since in the Philippines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourawesomeplanet.com/awesome/2015/10/the-halal-guys-ph.html|title=The Halal Guys: New York's Most Famous Street Cart now in Manila! @HalalGuys|website=Our Awesome Planet|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> *On January 2, 2016, a second California location opened in [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] at 1804 Ximeno Avenue.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yee|first1=Greg|title=The Halal Guys celebrates grand opening in Long Beach|url=http://www.presstelegram.com/business/20160102/the-halal-guys-celebrates-grand-opening-in-long-beach|accessdate=3 January 2016|work=Press-Telegram|date=2 January 2016}}</ref> *In May 2016 a store opened in [[East Brunswick, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2016/05/halal_guys_opens_first_new_jersey_location_more_to.html#incart_river_home|title=The Halal Guys open first New Jersey location, more to follow|website=Nj.com|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> *In May 2016 a store was opened in [[San Jose, California]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.mercurynews.com/eat-drink-play/2016/05/26/first-halal-guys-norcal-opens-san-jose/|title=NYC Halal Guys now open in San Jose – Eat, Drink, Play|date=2016-05-26|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref> *On August 12, 2016, a store was opened in [[Las Vegas]], Nevada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lasvegasweekly.com/intersection/2016/aug/10/halal-guys-las-vegas-chinatown/|title=The Halal Guys are here|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref> *On September 2, 2016, a store was opened in [[Springfield, Virginia]].<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/going-out-guide/wp/2016/08/31/the-halal-guys-is-opening-in-springfield-on-friday/|title=The Halal Guys is opening in Springfield and Fairfax on Friday|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> *On September 2, 2016, a store was opened in [[Fairfax, Virginia]].<ref name="auto"/> *On September 8, 2016, customers in Montreal, Quebec, lined up at [[Mackay Street]] and [[De Maisonneuve Boulevard|de Maisonneuve Boulevard West]] for the grand opening of the first Canadian location.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/halal-guys-opens-new-restaurant-in-montreal-1.3753461|title=Montrealers line up for taste of Big Apple as Halal Guys opens|website=Cbc.ca|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/the-halal-guys-famous-for-a-new-york-food-cart-are-coming-to-toronto-1.3153423|title=The Halal Guys, famous for a New York food cart, are coming to Toronto|website=Cbc.ca|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> As of May 2018, the two locations closed down, with a source citing that diners preferred local favorite [[Boustan]] instead of the NYC favorite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://montreal.eater.com/2018/5/23/17385014/the-halal-guys-montreal-closure-mackay-st-denis|title=Big Name NYC Street Meat Purveyors Bow out of Montreal|work=Eater Montreal|access-date=2018-05-24}}</ref> *On December 17, 2016, Halal Guys opened the first store in East Asia on exit 2 of [[Itaewon station]], Seoul, South Korea.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3027572|title=NYC street grub finds a home in Seoul|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> *On January 27, 2017, a store was opened in [[Tempe, Arizona]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azfamily.com/clip/13056308/the-halal-guys-open-first-arizona-restaurant-in-tempe|title=The Halal guys open first Arizona restaurant in Tempe|website=Azfamily.com|accessdate=4 May 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170511155855/http://www.azfamily.com/clip/13056308/the-halal-guys-open-first-arizona-restaurant-in-tempe#|archive-date=2017-05-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *On January 28, 2017, a store was opened in [[Chamblee, Georgia]], a suburb Northeast of [[Atlanta]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://whatnowatlanta.com/nycs-the-halal-guys-to-open-first-georgia-restaurant-january-28/|title=The Halal Guys To Open January 28 - What Now Atlanta|date=13 January 2017|website=Whatnowatlanta.com|accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref> *In April 2017, a store was opened in [[Union Township, Union County, New Jersey|Union, New Jersey]] located on Route 22. *In April 2017, The Halal Guys opened the first store in [[Jakarta]], Indonesia at [[Senayan City]] *In April 2017, a store was opened in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/entertainment/dining/2017/05/16/how-shreveport-made-cut-halal-guys/101721070/|title=How Shreveport made the cut for The Halal Guys|website=Shreveporttimes.com|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref> *On May 5, 2017, a store opened in [[Toronto]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Aksich|first1=Caroline|title=What’s on the menu at The Halal Guys, Toronto’s first location of the New York food-cart favourite|url=http://torontolife.com/food/restaurants/whats-menu-halal-guys-torontos-first-location-new-york-food-cart-favourite/|website=[[Toronto Life]]|publisher=[[St. Joseph Media]]|accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref> *On September 1, 2017, a store was opened in [[Orlando, Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.orlandoweekly.com/Blogs/archives/2017/08/29/the-halal-guys-in-waterford-lakes-is-now-in-soft-opening-mode|title=The Halal Guys in Waterford Lakes is now in soft opening mode|accessdate=29 Aug 2017}}</ref> *On September 15, 2017, a store was opened in [[Boston Theater District]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://boston.eater.com/2017/9/15/16311580|title=Arrival of the Halal Guys Makes Boston’s Dreams Come True Today|accessdate=19 Sep 2017}}</ref> *On September 30, 2017, a store was opened at [[The District (Tustin)]].<ref>{{cite web | title=The Halal Guys | website=The District at Tustin Legacy | url=https://thedistricttl.com/stores/district-the-district-of-tustin-legacy-the-halal-guys | access-date=December 28, 2017}}</ref> *On January 13, 2018, a store was opened at Puentes Hills Mall in Rowland Heights.<ref>[http://www.great-taste.net/tidbits-kudos/industry-news/halal-guys-announces-openings-new-southern-california-locations/ "Halal Guys (The) Announces Openings of New Southern California Locations"], great-taste.net</ref> *In January 2018, the 2nd store in Jakarta, Indonesia opened in the [[Grand Indonesia Shopping Town|Grand Indonesia]] mall. *On February 16, 2018, a store was opened in [[Rockville, Maryland]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bethesdamagazine.com/Bethesda-Beat/2018/The-Halal-Guys-Opens-Next-Week-in-Rockville/|title=The Halal Guys Opens Next Week in Rockville|date=5 February 2018|website=Bethesdamagazine.com|accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref> *In 2018, a store opened in Ashburn, Virgnia.
==Franchising== [[File:The Halal Guys at Springfield Plaza, interior.jpg|thumb|Interior of a franchise in Springfield, Virginia, in June 2018]] After being approached numerous times, holding off franchising to await a company that would respect their origins and core values, the Halal Guys hired [[Fransmart]], the [[Franchising|franchise]] development company behind the success and explosive growth of [[Qdoba Mexican Grill]] and [[Five Guys]], in June 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.salaamgateway.com/en/story/interviewits_a_halal_guys_world_new_york_citys_favorite_food_cart_goes_global-salaam28032016071518/|title=INTERVIEW-It’s a Halal Guys’ world: New York City’s favorite food cart goes global|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref> Within the first year of launching their franchise expansion campaign they closed deals for California; New Jersey; Connecticut; Virginia; Washington, DC; Houston and Austin, Texas ; Chicago, Illinois, as well as international deals for Canada, the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcasual.com/news/the-halal-guys-inks-5-unit-deal-for-toronto/|title=The Halal Guys inks 5-unit deal for Toronto|work=www.fastcasual.com}}</ref> In total this represents over 200 locations under development.
Despite initial concern that the company’s name or its association with [[Islamic culture|Muslim culture]] wouldn’t sit well with many Americans, [[Fransmart]] CEO Dan Rowe said that he has confidence in the company, and envisions that ”by the time they’re in Chattanooga, there will be so much good buzz, they’ll be excited to try it."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/15/nyregion/the-halal-guys-cashing-in-on-street-cred.html|title=The Halal Guys: Cashing In on Street Cred|date=2014-06-13|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-21|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
==Reception== In 2005, Chicken and Rice was one of four finalists for the "Vendy Award" presented by a New York City street vendor advocacy group known as the Street Vendor Project. Chicken and Rice eventually lost out to Rolf Babiel from [[Hallo Berlin]], a sausage cart on 54th and 5th.<ref name=StreetVendor>{{cite web|url=http://streetvendor.org/vendys/past-winners/nyc/|title=Vendy Awards Past Winners|accessdate=2014-02-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217112628/http://streetvendor.org/vendys/past-winners/nyc/#|archive-date=2013-12-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/11/nyregion/11vendors.html?pagewanted=print|title=In a Battle of Street-Food Vendors, the Wurst Wins|date=2005-11-11|author=Dana Bowen|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In addition, the popularity of the cart has been further aided by high-profile customers. Chef Christopher Lee, who was one of [[Food & Wine Magazine]]'s best new chefs of 2006, mentioned in an interview with the magazine that he "can't stay away from it" and once was there on Christmas Eve waiting two and a half hours in the cold.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/interview-christopher-lee|title=Interview with Best New Chef Christopher Lee|publisher=[[Food & Wine]]|accessdate=March 4, 2009}}</ref>
The cart has since become a prominent cuisine throughout New York City and has been heard as far as [[Hawaii]]. It has caused an increase in competition among street meat carts in [[Midtown Manhattan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-268850022.html|title=The Halal Guys|publisher=Islamic Business & Finance|date=2011-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/03/dining/03lunch.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|title=A Tour Guide Tames Lunch in Midtown|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2009-06-02|author=Julia Moskin|accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref> Lines commonly grow to over an hour's wait.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michelle-won/halal-chicken-rice-recipe_b_870318.html|title=Making NYC Street Meat: Chicken and Rice Recipe|author=Michelle Won|date=2011-06-02|work=[[The Huffington Post]]}}</ref> There is also a student club at [[New York University]] dedicated to the food cart.<ref>{{cite web |last=Yang |first=Emily |url=http://nyunews.com/news/2010/10/13/14club/ |title=Chicken, rice and a side of culture|work=[[Washington Square News]]|date= |accessdate=May 6, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725093036/http://nyunews.com/news/2010/10/13/14club/ |archivedate=July 25, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
The Halal Guys was awarded the 2014 Multicultural Award by the American Muslim Consumer Consortium for their promotion of diversity and multiculturalism, and their inclusivity to all minorities in America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/laila-alawa/what-is-it-with-that-whit_b_6158254.html|title=What Is it With That White Sauce?|last=Alawa|first=Laila|date=2014-11-14|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Companies|Food|New York City}} * [[List of chicken restaurants]] * [[List of restaurants in New York City]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.thehalalguysny.com/}}
{{Street food}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox Politician |name = Thierry Breton |image = Thierry BretonREA.jpg |imagesize = 200px |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1955|01|15}} |birth_place = {{flagicon|France}} Paris, France |office = [[Minister of the Economy, Finance and Industry (France)|Minister of the Economy, Finance and Industry]] |term_start = 25 February 2005 |term_end = 18 May 2007 |president = [[Jacques Chirac]] |primeminister = [[Dominique de Villepin]] |predecessor = [[Hervé Gaymard]] |successor = [[Jean-Louis Borloo]] |party = [[Rally for the Republic|RPR]] (1981–2002)
[[Union for a Popular Movement|UMP]] (2002–present) |occupation = Businessman |alma_mater = [[Supélec]] |religion = [[Protestantism]] }} '''Thierry Breton''' (born 15 January 1955 in [[Paris]]) is a French businessman, a former [[Professor]] at [[Harvard Business School]], and a former [[Finance minister]] of [[France]]. He has been Vice Chairman and CEO of [[Groupe Bull]], Chairman and CEO of [[Technicolor SA|Thomson-RCA]] (1997–2002), Chairman and CEO of [[France Télécom]] (2002–2005). Today an Honorary Chairman of both Thomson and France Telecom, he is, since 2008, Chairman and CEO of international information technology services company [[Atos]].{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/atos/ |title= Atos on Forbes Global 2000 list |date= May 2015 |website= Forbes |access-date= 21 June 2015}} He was from 2005 to 2007 the French [[Minister of the Economy, Finance and Industry (France)|Minister of Economy, Finance and Industry]] in the governments of Prime Ministers [[Jean-Pierre Raffarin]] and [[Dominique de Villepin]], [[Jacques Chirac]] being the President de la Republique. ==Early life & education== Born in the [[14th arrondissement of Paris]], Thierry Breton completed his middle and high school education at the ''Ecole alsacienne'' in Paris and [[University-preparatory school]] classes for the [[Grandes écoles]] at [[Lycée Louis-le-Grand]]. He received a master's degree in [[Electrical Engineering]] and [[Computer Science]] from [[École Supérieure d'Électricité]] (Supélec, now [[CentraleSupélec]]) in 1979 and later graduated from the ''Institut des hautes études de défense nationale'' ([[IHEDN]]).{{cite web |url=https://www.whoswho.fr/bio/thierry-breton_23519 |title=Biography of Thierry Breton |language= French |date=26 March 2015 |website=https://www.whoswho.fr/}} ==Manager== Thierry Breton began his career in 1979 as a professor of IT and Mathematics at the [[Lycée Français de New York]] as part of his military service through cooperation.{{cite web |url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/biography/A-E/Breton-Thierry-1955.html |title= Biography of Thierry Breton |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= Reference For Business |publisher= |access-date= 21 June 2015 |quote=}} In 1981 he created ''Forma Systems'', a systems-analysis and software-engineering company of which he became CEO until 1986. He became that year adviser to the French Ministry of Education and Research [[René Monory]] and designed open-air science and technology theme park [[Futuroscope]]. From 1990 to 1993, he was managing director of [[CGI Group]], a global information technology company. ===Groupe Bull=== In 1993, the French government hired Thierry Breton to help turn around troubled national computer maker [[Groupe Bull]]. As second in command, he managed to restructure the stock-market listed company and became in 1996 Vice-President of the Board of Directors. He is widely credited with pulling Bull from the edge of bankruptcy.{{cite journal |author= |title=Breton new CEO of France Telecom |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2002/BUSINESS/10/02/ftel/index.html |journal=CNN.com |location=Atlanta |publisher=CNN News Group |date=2 October 2002 |access-date= }} 18 years later - in August 2014 - he became President of the Board of Directors following the company's acquisition by Atos. ===Thomson=== In 1997, the French government named Thierry Breton chairman and CEO of Thomson Multimedia, a state-owned consumer-electronics company that was on the verge of collapse. A year before France's prime minister [[Alain Juppé]] unsuccessfully tried to sell the company to South Korea–based Daewoo for a single franc.{{cite journal |author= |title=Is It Too Late For Thomson? |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/stories/1997-08-24/is-it-too-late-for-thomson-intl-edition |journal=Businessweek Archives |location= |publisher= |date=24 August 1997 |access-date= }} Thierry Breton made stock offerings in order to generate cash and diversified the company's businesses,{{cite journal |author= |title=Acquisition of Technicolor Will Boost Thomson Profit |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jan/30/local/me-18802 |journal=Los Angeles Times|location= |publisher= |date= 30 January 2001 |access-date= }} figuring that consumer-electronics products were not high-end enough to consistently earn profits over the long term. Breton involved Thomson in interactive television, electronic publishing, and the Internet, as well as the higher-margin business of digital film-editing services. Thomson began manufacturing televisions with built-in software to run the electronic reference. Thomson's new ventures instilled investors with renewed confidence in the company and allowed Thierry Breton to attract bigname companies such as [[Microsoft]], [[Alcatel-Lucent|Alcatel]], [[NEC]], and the [[DirecTV]] division of Hughes Electronics.{{cite journal |author= |title=Thomson Multimedia Finds Friends With Deep Pockets |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/01/business/international-business-thomson-multimedia-finds-friends-with-deep-pockets.html |journal=New York Times|location= |publisher= |date= 1 August 1998 |access-date= }} By 1999 Thomson was turning a $230 million profit on sales of $6.5 billion. By the time Breton left in 2002, revenues had increased by more than 80 percent and Thomson was outperforming [[Sony]], [[Matsushita]], and [[Philips]], its major consumer-electronics competitors.{{cite journal |author= |title=Thomson CEO Is Rare For a French Tech Chief |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB1026678691908408840 |journal=The Wall Street Journal|location= |publisher= |date= 15 July 2002 |access-date= }} He was elected ''Strategist of the Year'' by French financial newspaper [[La Tribune]] and was named Honorary President of the company in September 2002 following his departure for France Télécom. ===France Télécom=== Widely acclaimed as a ''Turnaround whiz''{{cite journal |author= |title=Turnaround Whiz Breton Shakes Up France Telecom |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB1040073507228936753 |journal=Wall Street Journal |location= |publisher= |date=18 December 2002 |access-date= }}{{cite journal |author= |title=The Best European Performers |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/stories/2003-07-27/the-best-european-performers |journal=Bloomberg Business Magazine |location= |publisher= |date=27 July 2003 |access-date= }} Thierry Breton was named by French government as head of multinational telecommunications corporation [[France Télécom]] on 2 October 2002. In the past year, the company's share price had fallen about 70% while debts have ballooned to 60 billion euros ($54bn). A risky acquisition strategy that included mobile phone operator [[Orange (telecommunications)|Orange]], data carrier [[Equant]] and Internet service provider (ISP) [[Freeserve]] as well as several new, third-generation mobile phone licences had left France Telecom with the infamous title of the ''world's most indebted listed company''.{{cite journal |author= |title=France Telecom: Battling debt |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/1268527.stm |journal=Wall BBC News |location= |publisher= |date=19 April 2001 |access-date= }} At the time Thierry Breton took over share prices were worth less than 7 euros. Two months after his arrival these share prices had risen by 170%. He launched ''Ambition FT 2005'' and generated a three-tiered plan that called for cutting costs to increase cash flow, refinancing debt, and generating $16 billion from shareholders through a capital increase, all in efforts to save $30 billion over three years The operator was simultaneously facing an intensification of the competition in its long time market of France, as well as a demand from the [[ARCEP]] to unbundle [[ADSL]]. As a response to these challenges Thierry Breton notably ended [[Orange (telecommunications)|Orange]]’s venture on the stock market and took back complete control over the subsidiary and its earnings. In July 2003 he launched the plan ''Broadband internet for all'' with the objective of providing broadband to 90% of the French population. To do this he increased spending in the innovation sector by 20% and launched the charter ''Innovative Departments'' to speed up the development of broadband in rural areas. The following year the company recorded more than 7000 patents filed in France and abroad. In the same year France Télécom reintegrated with [[Wanadoo]] in order to integrate fixed telephony and [[service provider]] activities. In July 2004 Breton announced the launch of [[Livebox]], the operator's first [[Triple play (telecommunications)|Triple Play]] offer and France Télécom would become the first organisation to implement the concept of ''integrated operator''. In September 2004 the French government finalised the privatisation of France Télécom on which it had been working progressively since 1996. However, in accordance with the law of 31 December 2003 proposed and supported by Thierry Breton, the specific status of the employees was maintained. When he left the company for the Ministry of the Economy in February 2005 the share price was 23 euros. In less than three years the company’s debt was reduced to less than 40 billion euros. He was named as Honorary President of France Télécom. In January 2010 the ''Harvard Business Review'' first published a list of ''The 100 Best-Performing CEOs in the World'' which was based on an academic study comparing the performances of the heads of industry of the 2,000 biggest global companies, in their relevant fields, from 1995 to 2009. Thierry Breton held the 62nd position for his term as CEO of France Télécom.{{cite web |url=https://www.lib.uwo.ca/news/business/2010/01/09/bestperformingceosintheworld.html |title=Best Performing CEOs in the World |access-date=21 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150621213606/https://www.lib.uwo.ca/news/business/2010/01/09/bestperformingceosintheworld.html |archivedate=21 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }} ===Atos=== After two years of government service (2005-2007) he became in November 2008 the active chairman and CEO of [[Atos|Atos S.A.]], formerly Atos Origin.{{cite news|last=Chassany|first=Anne-Sylvaine|title=Atos Origin Board Fires Chief Germond, Hires Breton|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aOpHCL50TOTA|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=29 February 2012|date=17 November 2008}} On the announcement of his nomination the share price, which was previously valued at 18 euros, rose by 7.84%. In 2008 Atos generated a sales revenue of 5.5 billion euros with a headcount of 50,000 employees but according to Thierry Breton was "managed too compartmentally" and the company’s inferior profitability margins compared to those of its competitors required a complete transformation plan. In July 2011 he orchestrated the acquisition of the IT activities of German industry group [[Siemens]] which allowed the company to rank number one among the European IT services players and in the Top 5 worldwide, with 75 000 employees in 42 countries. The deal, valued at €850m ($1.1bn), was the biggest Franco-German transaction since an alliance between Germany’s premium carmaker [[Daimler AG|Daimler]] and France’s [[Renault]] early this year.{{cite journal |author= |title=Siemens strikes tie-up deal with Atos |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/6ad4362c-07ca-11e0-a568-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3dh1zpbLy |journal=FT |location= |publisher= |date=14 December 2010 |access-date= }} The operation was lauded by the financial markets and the Atos share price rose by 11.6%. With the integration of 28,000 engineers Atos became one of the most important Franco-German industrial collaborations since [[Airbus]], illustrated particularly by a financial partnership (Siemens took 15% of Atos’ capital), and a common investment fund of 100 million euros was created as well as a joint response to international tenders. This strategy was awarded the prize for ''Industrial cooperation'' by the Franco-German Chamber of Commerce and Industry. In 2012 Thierry Breton adopted the [[Societas Europaea]] for Atos which gave the company two headquarters, one in France and a second in Munich, Germany. Furthermore, he participated in other European institutional projects in which the Franco-German partnership played a central role such as the [[European Commission]]’s European Cloud Partnership (2012-2014) over which he co-presided with Jim Snabe, the co-CEO of the German world leader in software [[SAP SE|SAP]]. In May 2014 Thierry Breton launched a friendly takeover on French historic IT industry player Bull, turning Atos into the number one European company and one of the major global players in [[Big Data]] and [[Cybersecurity]].{{cite journal |author= |title=Atos Takes Control of French Rival Bull |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/atos-takes-control-of-french-rival-bull-1408516048 |journal=Wall Street Journal|location= |publisher= |date=20 August 2014 |access-date= }} This acquisition, again commended by the markets (Atos’ share price rose by 6.2% and Bull’s by 21.9% the day of the announcement) notably allowed the company to position itself in the [[Supercomputing]] segment and to become the sole only European manufacturer. Six months later he announced Atos’ acquisition of [[Xerox]]’s IT outsourcing activities as well as a strategic partnership with the American company.{{cite journal |author= |title=French Computer-Services Company Atos to Buy Xerox’s IT Outsourcing Unit |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/french-computer-services-company-atos-to-buy-xeroxs-it-outsourcing-unit-1418949455 |journal=Wall Street Journal |location= |publisher= |date=19 December 2014 |access-date= }} This operation, which was viewed favorably by the Stock Market, made Atos one of the five largest digital companies in the world. The company had doubled in size within six years with a headcount of around 100,000 employees. Thierry Breton got World attention after an interview with the [[Wall Street Journal]] in 2011 when he reiterated his intention to ban internal Email, dubbed as "the pollution of the information age", at Atos within 18 months (known as the [[Zero-Email Strategy]]), replacing internal emails by a set of Enterprise Social Networks, Enterprise Instant Messaging, Collaborative tools etc..., both being developed inhouse and partially aggregated from other vendors.{{cite news|last1=Colchester|first1=Max|last2=Amiel|first2=Geraldine|title=The IT Boss Who Shuns Email|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204452104577060103165399154?mod=googlenews_wsj|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=5 December 2011|date=28 November 2011}} In 2012 he was elected ''Strategist of the Year'' by French financial newspaper [[Les Échos (France)|Les Echos]] for his management of Atos. In May 2015 the company’s market capitalization rose to 7.29 billion euros, an increase of more than 5 billion euros compared with November 2008 when Thierry Breton took over office. The market share price of Atos grew by 268% in five years. ==Minister of Finance== Having already been proposed twice to succeed [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] as Finance Minister, Thierry Breton was appointed on 24 February 2005, replacing [[Hervé Gaymard]],.{{cite news|last1=de Beaupuy|first1=Francois|last2=Vandore|first2=Emma|title=Chirac Names France Telecom's Breton as New Finance Minister|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aOOf4zt1fvbQ&refer=europe|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=29 February 2012|date=25 February 2005}} During his two and a half years at the head of Bercy he centred his economic policy on the need to reform [[public finances]], specifically in order to reduce debt.{{cite journal |author= |title=Paris rediscovers fiscal discipline |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/b132c504-4cfb-11db-b03c-0000779e2340.html#axzz3dh1zpbLy |archive-url=https://archive.is/20151222175516/http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/b132c504-4cfb-11db-b03c-0000779e2340.html#axzz3dh1zpbLy |dead-url=yes|journal=FT |location= |publisher= |date=26 September 2006 |access-date= }} In June 2005 he declared that France ''lives beyond its means'', a sentiment echoing the words of the Prime Minister [[Raymond Barre]] in 1976. He stated to the French people that the entirety of their income tax would serve only to finance the interest payments on the national debt. A month later he set up a commission presided over by [[BNP Paribas]] CEO [[Michel Pébereau]] which was given the task of ''breaking the pattern of public debt''. He stipulated the maintenance of [[public deficit]] below a level of 3% of GDP in 2005 and 2006 as his primary goal. At the end of 2005 France’s deficit fell to 2.9% of its GDP after three consecutive years of surpassing the figure of 3%. In 2006 the public deficit was further reduced to 2.5% and public debt was recorded to have dramatically fallen to 63.9% of GDP. For the first time since 1995 the country’s budget was in a situation of primary surplus. At the same time France’s GDP rose by 2.1% in 2006 compared with 1.7% in 2005. In October 2005 Breton proposed a law on "the modernization of the economy" which was voted in the same year and looked to prioritize SMEs’ access to financial markets, encourage research and promote giving employees a stake in the company’s outcomes. On this occasion he also announced himself in favor of the status of the [[Societas Europaea]] being written into French legislation to allow businesses to operate throughout the EU on the basis of a unified set of financial rules. At the same time he led a reform for fiscal simplification which attempted to reduce the number of tax brackets from seven to four and put in place a pre-filled internet based declaration of revenues. During this period he unveiled the concept of the [[tax shield]], which he would initiate in 2006 at a level of 60% excepting health insurance and social debt reimbursement. This was taken up again by Nicolas Sarkozy in 2007 with a lowering of the level to 60% and an inclusion of health insurance and social debt reimbursement. Thierry Breton wanted France to be the first country to move forward in developing its immaterial heritage. Thus in March 2007 he entrusted a report to [[Maurice Lévy]] and [[Jean-Pierre Jouyet]] on the economy of the immaterial with the goal of creating an agency for the immaterial heritage of the state which ambition would be to valorize the state’s immaterial assets (use of image; brands etc.) This one-of-a-kind agency was put in place on 23 April 2007. This immaterial heritage was recorded as 10 billion euros worth of assets in the state’s annual report in 2010. In February 2007 the unemployment rate was at 8.4%, the lowest recorded score since June 1983. He finished his term on 15 May 2007 at the end of Jacques Chirac’s five-year term. The handover of power to [[Jean-Louis Borloo]], named as Minister of the Economy by the newly elected President of the French Republic Nicolas Sarkozy, took place the following day. ==Board member== He served as director in many boards such as: [[AXA]]; [[La Poste (France)|La Poste]]; [[Dexia]]; [[Schneider Electric]]; [[Bouygues Telecom]]. He sits today on the board of directors of [[Carrefour]] where he chairs the Compensation and Benefits Committee. He also is member of [[Bank of America]]'s Global Advisory Council.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/25/nc-bank-of-america-idUSnBw9jFx6fa+110+BSW20130125 |title=Bank of America Forms Global Advisory Council |author= |date=25 January 2013 |website=Reuters |publisher= |access-date= |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924173513/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/25/nc-bank-of-america-idUSnBw9jFx6fa+110+BSW20130125 |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }} ==Academic career== After leaving the government, he has been a Professor at [[Harvard Business School]] (2007–2008) where he taught Leadership and Corporate Accountability (LCA). He has been also the Chairman of the [[University of Technology of Troyes]] in France from 1997 to 2005. ==Author== He is the author of many books about information technology and economy, and co-author of a novel about cyberspace. * 1984 : ''[[Softwar]]'', The Emergence of Computer Virus as a weapon of mass destruction (La Guerre douce), Thierry Breton - Denis Beneich, éd. Robert Laffont, Paris ; (translated in 25 countries). * 1985 : ''Vatican III'', The emergence of a Word made of information based Communities , Thierry Breton, éd. Robert Laffont, Paris * 1987 : ''Netwar'', The Networks War (La guerre des réseaux), Thierry Breton, éd. Robert Laffont, Paris * 1991 : ''La Dimension invisible'', The Emergence of Information Society (Le défi du temps et de l'information),Thierry Breton, éd. Odile Jacob, Paris * 1992 : ''La Fin des illusions'',The end of the Geek Age, Thierry Breton, Plon, Paris. * 1993 : ''Le Télétravail en France'', An early description of Teleworking in France, Thierry Breton, La Documentation française, Paris. * 1994 : ''Le Lièvre et la Tortue'', France and The Knowledge Revolution, Thierry Breton - Christian Blanc, éd. Plon, Paris. * 1994 : ''Les Téléservices en France'', An early description of the internet word, Thierry Breton, La Documentation française, Paris. * 2007 : ''Antidette'', How to reduce the over spending and major indebtness of France, Thierry Breton, Plon, Paris. == Decorations and awards == He is an officer of the [[Légion d'honneur]] and a commander of the [[Ordre National du Mérite]]. He is also a member of [[Le Siècle (think tank)|Le Siècle]].Frédéric Saliba, 'Le pouvoir à la table du Siècle', in ''[[Stratégies]]'', issue 1365, 14 April 2005, p. 49 [http://www.strategies.fr/emploi-formation/management/r36900W/14-le-pouvoir-a-la-table-du-siecle.html] ===Decorations=== * 2010 : Commander in the [[Order of Ouissam Alaouite]], Morocco. * 2008 : Officer in the national Order of [[Légion d'honneur]], France. * 2006 : Grand Cross in the [[Order of Merit]] (Al Merito de Chile), Chile. * 2006 : Grand officer in the national [[Order of the Southern Cross]] (Ordem Nacional do Cruzeiro do Sul), Brazil. * 2006 : Commander in the [[Order of Civil Merit]] (orden del Merito Civil), Spain. * 2004 : Commander in the [[National Order of Merit (France)]] (ordre national du Mérite), France. * 2001 : Honorary Citizen of the City of [[Foshan]], Guangdong Province, People Republic of China. ===Awards=== * 2015 : [[Maximilian von Montgelas|Montgelas]] Prize, for outstanding actions in favor of French-German cooperation, Munich, Germany.{{cite web|title=Ehrung für Bildungsminister Dr. Ludwig Spaenle und Frankreichs Finanzminister a.D. Thierry Breton|url=https://www.bayern.landtag.de/aktuelles/veranstaltungen/gaeste-und-begegnungen/24092015-ehrung-fuer-bildungsminister-dr-ludwig-spaenle-und-frankreichs-finanzminister-ad-thierry-breton/|website=Bayerischer Landtag|publisher=Bavarian State Parliament|accessdate=19 October 2015|language=German|date=24 September 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box|title=[[Minister of the Economy, Finance and Industry (France)|Minister of the Economy, Finance and Industry]]|before=[[Hervé Gaymard]]|after=[[Jean-Louis Borloo]]|years=2005–2007}} {{s-end}} {{Finance Ministers of France}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Breton, Thierry}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lycée Louis-le-Grand alumni]] [[Category:Supélec alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Business School faculty]] [[Category:Politicians from Paris]] [[Category:Politicians of the French Fifth Republic]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of Ouissam Alaouite]] [[Category:French Ministers of Finance]] [[Category:Officiers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Commanders of the National Order of Merit (France)]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:TOYP Awardees]] [[Category:N M Rothschild & Sons people]]

'''Timeline of [[trade union|organized labor]] history''' <!-- __NOTOC__ -->
<center> {{hlist |[[#1600s|1600s]] |[[#1740s|1740s]] |[[#1760s|1760s]] |[[#1770s|1770s]] |[[#1780s|1780s]] |[[#1790s|1790s]] |[[#1800s|1800s]] |[[#1810s|1810s]] |[[#1820s|1820s]] |[[#1830s|1830s]] |[[#1840s|1840s]] |[[#1850s|1850s]] |[[#1860s|1860s]] |[[#1870s|1870s]] |[[#1880s|1880s]] |[[#1890s|1890s]] |[[#1900s|1900s]] |[[#1910s|1910s]] |[[#1920s|1920s]] |[[#1930s|1930s]] |[[#1940s|1940s]] |[[#1950s|1950s]] |[[#1960s|1960s]] |[[#1970s|1970s]] |[[#1980s|1980s]] |[[#2000s|2000s]] |[[#2010s|2010s]]}} </center>
==1600–99==
;1619 (United States) :[[1619 Jamestown Polish craftsmen strike]]
;1636 (United States) :[[Maine]] Indentured Servant's and Fisherman's Mutiny.<ref name="fillippelli_p019">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing, Inc.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xix}}</ref>
;1648 (United States) :[[Boston]] Coopers and Shoemakers form guilds.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1661 (United States) :[[Virginia's Indentured Servants' Plot]].<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1663 (United States) :[[Maryland]] Indentured Servants' Strike.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1675 (United States) :[[Boston]] Ship Carpenters' Protest.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
[[File:Howard Pyle - The Burning of Jamestown.jpg|thumb|alt=Howard Pyle - The Burning of Jamestown|''The Burning of Jamestown'' by Howard Pyle depicts the burning of Jamestown, Virginia during [[Bacon's Rebellion]] (1676–77).]]
;1676 (United States) :[[Bacon's Rebellion]] in [[Virginia]].<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1677 (United States) :New York City Carter's Strike.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1684 (United States) :New York City Carter's Strike.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
==1700–99==
===1740s===
;1741 (United States) :New York City Bakers' Strike.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
===1760s===
;1768 (United States) :[[Florida]] Indentured Servants' Revolt.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
===1770s===
;1774 (United States) :[[Hibernia, New Jersey]], Ironworks Strike.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1778 (United States) :Journeymen printers in New York combine to increase their wages.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
===1780s===
;1781 (Austria) :Holy Roman Emperor, [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]], issues the [[Serfdom Patent (1781)|Serfdom Patent of 1781]], to abolish serfdom throughout the Hapsburg lands.
===1790s=== ;1791 (United States) :[[Philadelphia]] carpenters conduct first strike in the building trades in the United States.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" /> ;1792 (United States) :Philadelphia has first local union in the United States organized to conduct collective bargaining.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" /> ;1794 (United States) :[[Federal Society of Journeymen Cordwainers]] formed in [[Philadelphia]].<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1797 (United States) :Profit sharing originated at [[Albert Gallatin]]'s [[New Geneva Glass Works|glassworks]] in [[New Geneva, Pennsylvania]].
;1799 (England) : [[Combination Act 1799|Combination Act]] outlawed trade unionism and collective bargaining by workers.<ref name="thompson_1963_p239">{{cite book |last=Thompson|first=E.P.|title=[[The Making of the English Working Class]]|year=c1963, p1966|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0-14-013603-6|pages=181}}</ref>
==1800–99==
===1800s=== ;1805 (United States) :Journeymen Cordwainer's union includes a closed-shop clause in its constitution in New York City.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1806 (United States) :''[[Commonwealth v. Pullis]]'' was the first known court case arising from a labor strike in the United States. After a three-day trial, the jury found the defendants guilty of "a combination to raise their wages" and fined.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
===1810s=== ;1816 (England) :Food riots broke out in [[East Anglia]]. Workers demanded a double wage and for the setting of triple prices for food.<ref name=thompson_1963_p225_226>{{cite book |last=Thompson|first=E.P.|title=The Making of the English Working Class|year=c1963, p1966|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|isbn=9780394703220|pages=225–226}}</ref>
===1820s=== ;1824 (England) :The [[Combination Act 1799|Combination Act of 1799]] was repealed.<ref name="thompson_1963_p239"/>
;1824 (United States) :[[Pawtucket, Rhode Island]], Textile Strike.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1825 (United States) :[[United Tailoresses of New York]] organized in New York City.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1825 (United States) :[[Boston House Carpenter's Strike]] <ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1827 (United States) :[[Mechanics' Union of Trades' Associations]] formed in Philadelphia.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1827 (United States) :[[Philadelphia Carpenter's Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p019" />
;1828 (United States) :[[Workingmen's Party]] was organized in [[Philadelphia]] by the [[Mechanics' Union of Trades' Associations]].<ref name="fillippelli_p019" /><ref name="foner_1978_p127">{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Volume 1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Republic|year=p1978, c1947|publisher=International Publishers|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=127–129}}</ref>
;23 April 1829 (United States) : [[Committee of Fifty (1829)|Committee of Fifty]], a group of prominent trade unionists in New York City, organized to resist efforts by business owners to revoke the 10-hour workday and reinstate the 11-hour workday.<ref name="foner_1978_p130">{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Volume 1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Republic|year=p1978, c1947|publisher=International Publishers|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=130}}</ref> Their efforts lead directly to the forming of the [[Workingmen's Party of New York]].<ref name="foner_1978_p130" />
;1829 (United States) :[[Workingmen's Party of New York]] formed.<ref name="fillippelli_p019" /><ref name="foner_1978_p130" />
===1830s=== ;1831 (United States) :[[New England Association of Farmers, Mechanics, and other Workingmen]] formed.<ref name="fillippelli_p020">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xx}}</ref>
;9 January 1831 (England) :Twenty-three workers from Buckingham were sentenced to death for destruction of a paper machine by one of a number of Special Commissions sent to East Anglia to suppress insurgent workers by the Whig Ministry.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226>{{cite book |last=Thompson|first=E.P.|title=The Making of the English Working Class|year=c1963, p1966|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|isbn=9780394703220|pages=226}}</ref>
[[File:FrameBreaking-1812.jpg|thumb|alt=FrameBreaking, 1812|Frame-breakers, or Luddites, smashing a loom. Machine-breaking was criminalized by the Parliament of the United Kingdom as early as 1721, but as a result of continued opposition to mechanisation the Frame-Breaking Act 1812 made the death penalty available: see "Criminal damage in English law".]]
;11 January 1831 (England) :Three workers in Dorset were sentenced to death for extorting money and two workers were sentenced to death for robbery by one of the Special Commissions sent by the Whig Ministry to suppress insurgent workers.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226 />
:Fifty-five workers in Norwich were convicted of "machine breaking and rioting" by one of the Special Commissions sent by the Whig Ministry to suppress insurgent workers.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226 />
:Three workers in Ipswich were convicted of extorting money by one of the Special Commissions sent by the Whig Ministry to suppress insurgent workers.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226 />
:Twenty-six workers in Petworth were convicted of "machine breaking and rioting" by one of the Special Commissions sent by the Whig Ministry to suppress insurgent workers.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226 />
:"Upwards of thirty" workers in Gloucester were convicted of "machine breaking and rioting" by one of the Special Commissions sent by the Whig Ministry to suppress insurgent workers.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226 />
:Twenty-nine workers in Oxford were convicted of "machine breaking and rioting" by one of the Special Commissions sent by the Whig Ministry to suppress insurgent workers.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226 />
;1832 (United States) :[[Boston Ship Carpenters' Ten-Hour Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1833 (United States) :[[Lynn, Massachusetts]]' Shoebinders' Protest begins.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
[[File:Black-eyed Sue and Sweet Poll of Plymouth taking leave of their lovers who are going to Botany Bay.jpeg|thumb|right|Women in England mourning their lovers who are soon to be transported to [[Botany Bay]], 1792]]
;1834 (England) :The [[Tolpuddle Martyrs]], agricultural workers who formed a trade union in [[Tolpuddle]] in [[Dorsetshire]], were sentenced by a Whig Ministry Special Commission to [[Penal transportation|transportation]] to a penal colony in Australia.<ref name=thompson_1963_p226 />
;March 1834 (United States) :[[National Trades' Union]] formed in New York when the [[New York General Trades' Union]] solicited labor organizations from around the country to send delegates to a national convention.<ref name="foner_1978_p114">{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the Labor Movement in the United States|volume=1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Republic|year=p1978, c1947|publisher=International Publishers|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=114}}</ref> This union was the first attempt to create a national labor federation.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1834 (United States) :[[Lowell Mill Girls#Strikes of 1834 and 1836|Lowell, Massachusetts Mill Women's Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1834 (United States) :[[Manayunk, Pennsylvania]] Textile Strike.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1835 (United States) :Carpenters, masons, and stone-cutters began a strike as part of the [[Ten-Hour Movement]] among skilled workers.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" /> They drafted a strike circular in Boston outlining their demands and seeking assistance from other tradespeople. Wherever this circular was distributed, a strike in favor of the ten-hour workday erupted. The [[1835 Philadelphia general strike]], in which workers successfully struck for shorter working hours and higher wages, was influenced by the Boston circular.<ref name=foner_v01>{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the labor movement in the United States. |volume=1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Federation of Labor|year=p1978, c1947|publisher=International Publishers Co.|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=116}}</ref>
;3 July 1835 (United States) :Textile workers, many of whom were children of Irish descent, launched the [[1835 Paterson textile strike]] in the silk mills in [[Paterson, New Jersey]] fighting for the 11-hour day, 6 days a week.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1836 (United States) :[[National Cooperative Association of Cordwainers]] formed in New York City. This association was the first national union for a specific craft.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1836 (United States) :[[Lowell Mill Girls#Strikes of 1834 and 1836|Llowell, Massachusetts, Mill Women's Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1836 (United States) :[[New York City Tailors' Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1836 (United States) :[[Philadelphia's Bookbinders' Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
===1840s=== ;1840 (United States) :Ten-hour day for federal employees on federal public works projects without loss of pay established by President [[Martin Van Buren]] by executive order.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" /><ref name="foner_1978_p163">{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Volume 1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Republic|year=p1978, c1947|publisher=International Publishers|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=163}}</ref>
;1842 (United States) :[[Ten-hour Republican Association]] was formed by New England mechanics to pressure the Massachusetts legislature to establish a ten-hour workday throughout the state.<ref name="foner_1978_p202">{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Volume 1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Republic|year=p1978, c1947|publisher=International Publishers|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=202}}</ref>
;March 1842 (United States) :''[[Commonwealth v. Hunt]]'' was a landmark legal decision by the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] on the subject of labor unions. Chief Justice Lemuel Shaw ruled that unions were legal organizations and had the right to organize and strike. Before this decision, labor unions which attempted to 'close' or create a unionized workplace could be charged with conspiracy.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" /> See ''[[Commonwealth v. Pullis]]''
[[File:FGA Constitution.jpg|thumb|right|1836 Constitution of the Lowell Factory Girls Association]]
;1844 (United States) :[[Lowell Mill Girls#Lowell Female Labor Reform Association|Lowell Female Labor Reform Association]] formed.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
; April 1844 (United States) :[[Fall River Mechanics' Association]] established 'The Mechanic', a weekly paper dedicated "to advocate the cause of the oppressed Mechanic and Laborer in all its bearings."<ref name="foner_1978_p203">{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Volume 1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Republic|year=p1978, c1947|publisher=International Publishers|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=203}}</ref>
;1847 (Scotland) :The [[Educational Institute of Scotland]], the oldest teachers' trade union in the world, was founded.
;1847 (United States) :[[New Hampshire]] is first state to establish the ten-hour workday.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1848 (United States) :[[Pennsylvania]]'s child labor law establishes the age of 12 as the minimum age for workers in commercial occupations.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1848 (Germany) Founding of the Allgemeine Deutsche Arbeiter-Verbrüderung (General German Workers-Brotherhood) <ref name="roth_p159">Roland Roth, Dieter Rucht (edt), ''Die Sozialen Bewegungn in Deutschland seit 1945, Ein Handbuch'' (Frankfurt/New York, Campus Verlag, 2009), Page 159</ref>
===1850s=== ;1850 (United States) :[[New York City Tailor's Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;July 1851 (United States) :Two railroad strikers are shot dead and others injured by the state militia in [[Portgage, New York|Portage]], New York.
;1852 (United States) :[[International Typographical Union|Typographical Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;21 April 1856 (Australia) :Stonemasons and building workers in [[Melbourne]] achieve an [[eight-hour day]], the first organized workers in the world to achieve an 8-hour day, with no loss of pay.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}}<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sparrow|first1=Jeff|last2=Sparrow|first2=Jill|title=A secret history|date=2002|publisher=Vulgar Press|location=Carlton North, Vic.|isbn=0957735243|edition=reprinted|url=http://ergo.slv.vic.gov.au/explore-history/fight-rights/workers-rights/winning-8-hour-day|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref>
;1859 (United States) :[[International Molders and Foundry Workers Union of North America|Iron Molders' International Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
===1860s=== [[File:Labor Day Parade. Union St., N.Y, from Robert N. Dennis collection of stereoscopic views.jpg|thumb|alt=Labor Day Parade, Union St., N.Y., ca. 1859-1899 |Labor Day Parade. Union St., N.Y, circa 1859–1899, from Robert N. Dennis collection of stereoscopic views]] ;1860 (United States) [[New England Shoemakers Strike of 1860]] :800 women operatives and 4,000 workmen marched during a shoemaker's strike in [[Lynn, Massachusetts|Lynn]], [[Massachusetts]].
;1863 (United States) :The first railroad labor union, The Brotherhood of the Footboard (later renamed the [[Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers]]) is formed in [[Marshall, Michigan|Marshall]], [[Michigan]].<ref name="fillippelli_p020" /> It is headed by [[William D. Robinson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ble-t.org/blet150/history.aspx |title=History|publisher=Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen|accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
;1864 (Europe) :[[International Workingmen's Association]] (often called the First International) is founded.
;1864 (United States) :[[Cigar Makers' Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1864 July 21 (United States) :[[Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1866 (United States) :[[National Labor Union]] formed - 1st national labor federation in the US.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1866 (United States) :Molders' Lockout.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
[[File:NationalColoredUnionConventionHarpersWeekly1869.jpg|thumb|alt=National Colored Union Convention, Harpers Weekly,1869|February 6, 1869 Illustration from Harper's Weekly of the Colored National Labor Union convention in Washington, D.C. Store Web page states: "from Harper's Weekly magazine with 6 x 9 [inch] wood-engraved illustration of the National Colored Convention in Session at Washington, D.C."]]
;1867 (United States) :[[Order of the Knights of St. Crispin]], a union for factory workers in the shoe industry, founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1868 (Germany) :The [[Allgemeiner Deutscher Gewerkschaftsbund]] (ADGB)(Federation of General German Civil Servants) was founded and represented 142,000 workers.<ref name="ICTUR">{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]]| edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7|display-editors=etal}}</ref>
;1868 (United States) :First U.S. federal eight-hour law passed. This law only applied to laborers, workmen, and mechanics employed by the U.S. federal government.<ref name="fillippelli_p020" />
;1869 (United States) :[[Colored National Labor Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p021">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xxi}}</ref>
[[File:Uriah-stephens-circa-1900.gif|thumb| alt=Uriah Stephens, pre-1882 | [[Uriah Stephens]], pre-1882. Stephens (1821 - 1882) was a U.S. labor leader. He led nine Philadelphia garment workers to found the Knights of Labor in 1869, a more successful early national union.]]
;1869 (United States) :[[Uriah Smith Stephens]] organized a new union known as the [[Knights of Labor]].<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1869 (United States) :[[Collar Laundry Union|Collar Laundry Union Strike]] in [[Troy, New York]].<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
===1870s=== ;1870 (United States) :The first written contract between coal miners and coal miner operators signed.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1872 (Europe) :[[Karl Marx]] ejects [[Mikhail Bakunin]] and the other anarchists from the [[International Workingmen's Association]]
;1873 (United States) :In 1873 the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen was established. In 1906 it became the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen & Enginemen.
;13 January 1874 (United States) :The original [[Tompkins Square Riot (1874)|Tompkins Square Riot]] occurs in New York City.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" /> As unemployed workers demonstrated in New York City's Tompkins Square Park, a detachment of mounted police charged into the crowd, beating men, women and children indiscriminately with billy clubs and leaving hundreds of casualties in their wake.
;1874 (United States) :[[Peter M. Arthur]] elected Grand Chief of the [[Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers]]. He remained in office until his death.<ref name="foner_p560">{{cite book |last=Foner|first=Philip S.|title=History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Volume 1: From Colonial Times to the Founding of the American Federation of Labor|year=c1947, p1978|publisher=International Publishers|location=New York|isbn=0717803767|pages=560}}</ref>
;1875 (United States) :The [[Molly Maguires]] are convicted for the anthracite coalfield murders.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1875 (United States) :[[Anthracite Coal Strike]] takes place.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1876 (United States) :[[Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel, and Tin Workers]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1876 (United States) :[[Workingmen's Party]] is founded. It later becomes the [[Socialist Labor Party]].<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
[[File:AlexanderCampbell.png|thumb|alt=Alexander Campbell|Photograph of Alexander Campbell "Father of the Greenback Party"]]
;1876 (United States) :[[Greenback Party]] is founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1877 (United States) :[[Cigar Makers' International Union]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1877 (United States) :San Francisco [[San Francisco riot of 1877|Anti-Chinese Riots]] occur.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;12 February 1877 (United States) :The [[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]<ref name="fillippelli_p021" /> -- U.S. railroad workers began strikes to protest wage cuts.{{Ref|yellen}} It started in [[Martinsburg, West Virginia]], and then spread to many other states.
;14 July 1877 (United States) :A general strike halted the movement of U.S. railroads. In the following days, strike riots spread across the United States. The next week, federal troops were called out to force an end to the nationwide strike. At the "[[Battle of the Viaduct]]" in the Pilsen neighborhood of Chicago, between protesting members of the [[Chicago German Furniture Workers Union]], now Local 1784 of the Carpenters Union, and federal troops killed 30 workers and wounded over 100.
[[File:1877-slp-congress.jpg|thumb|right|260px|The [[Socialist Labor Party of America]] does not seem to have used its distinctive arm-and-hammer logo until it appeared on the front page of ''The Workmen's Advocate'' in 1885.]]
;1878 (United States) :[[Socialist Labor Party of America]] founded when the [[Workingmen's Party of the United States]] voted to change its name at its December 1877 convention.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1878 (United States) :[[Greenback Labor Party]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1878 (United States) :[[International Labor Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
===1880s=== ;1881 (United States and Canada) :[[Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Unions]], the ender of the [[American Federation of Labor]], was founded in the United States and Canada.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1881 (United States) :[[Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners]] was founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1881 (United States) :[[Revolutionary Socialist Labor Party]] was founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1882 (United States) :[[Cohoes, New York, Cotton Mill Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;5 September 1882 (United States) :Thirty thousand workers marched in the first [[Labor Day]] parade in New York City.
[[File:1919-TALC-Canada.jpg|thumb|600px|Thirty-fifth annual meeting of the Trades and Labour Congress, Hamilton, 1919.]]
;1883 (Canada) :The [[Trades and Labour Congress of Canada]] (TLC), a Canada-wide central federation of trade unions was formed.
;1883 (United States) :[[International Working People's Association]] formed.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1883 (United States) :[[Lynchburg, Virginia, Tobacco Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1883 (United States) :[[Molder's Lockout]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1884 (United States) :The [[Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Unions]], forerunner of the [[American Federation of Labor]], passed a resolution stating that "8 hours shall constitute a legal day's work from and after May 1, 1886."
;1884 (United States) :[[United States Department of Labor#History|Federal Bureau of Labor]] established in the [[U.S. Department of the Interior]].<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1884 (United States) :[[Fall River, Massachusetts, Textile Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1884 (United States) :[[Union Pacific Railroad Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1885 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] passed the [[Foran Act]] outlawing immigration of laborers on contract.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1885 (United States) :[[Cloakmakers' General Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1885 (United States) :[[McCormick Harvesting Machine Company Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1885 (United States) :[[Great Southwest Railroad Strike of 1886#Causes and history of the strike|Southwest Railroad Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1885 (United States) :[[Yonkers, New York, Carpet Weaver' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p021" />
;1885 (United States) :Ten coal-mining activists ("[[Molly Maguires]]") were hanged in [[Pennsylvania]].
;1886 (United States) :[[Augusta, Georgia]] Textile strike occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xxii}}</ref>
;1886 (United States) :[[Cowboy Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1886 (United States) :[[McCormick Harvesting Machine Company Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1886 (United States) :[[Troy, New York, Collar Laundresses Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:Great Railway Strike 1886 - E St Louis.jpg|thumb|right|U.S. Marshalls attempt to start a train during the strike in [[East St. Louis, Illinois]].]]
;March 1886 (United States) :The [[Great Southwest Railroad Strike of 1886]] was a labor union strike against the [[Union Pacific Railroad|Union Pacific]] and [[Missouri Pacific Railroad|Missouri Pacific]] railroads involving more than 200,000 workers.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1 May 1886 (United States) :Workers protested in the streets to demand the universal adoption of the [[eight-hour day]]. Hundreds of thousands of American workers had joined the [[Knights of Labor]]. The movement ultimately failed.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:JMRusk.jpg|thumb|left|Representative Jeremiah M. Rusk]]
;1 May 1886 (United States) :[[Bay View Tragedy]]: About 2,000 Polish workers walked off their jobs and gathered at St. Stanislaus Church in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], angrily denouncing the [[eight-hour day|ten-hour workday]]. The protesters marched through the city, calling on other workers to join them. All but one factory was closed down as sixteen thousand protesters gathered at Rolling Mills. Wisconsin Governor [[Jeremiah Rusk]] called the state militia. The militia camped out at the mill while workers slept in nearby fields. On the morning of 5 May, as protesters chanted for the eight-hour workday, General Treaumer ordered his men to shoot into the crowd, some of whom were carrying sticks, bricks, and scythes, leaving seven dead at the scene, including a child.<ref name="WLHS">[http://www.wisconsinlaborhistory.org/bayview.html Wisconsin Labor History Society: Bay View Story] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051108103123/http://www.wisconsinlaborhistory.org/bayview.html |date=8 November 2005 }}</ref><ref name="LttP">[http://linkstothepast.com/milwaukee/bayviewmassacre.html Bay View Massacre, Milwaukee County Genealogy]</ref>
:The ''[[Milwaukee Journal]]'' reported that eight more would die within twenty-four hours, adding that Governor Rusk was to be commended for his quick action in the matter.
[[File:Samuel Gompers cph.3a02952.jpg|thumb|Samuel Gompers]]
;1886 (United States) :[[American Federation of Labor]] founded. [[Samuel Gompers]] served as first president.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:Haymarket Flier.jpg|thumb|Haymarket Flier]]
[[File:HaymarketRiot-Harpers.jpg|thumb|Haymarket Riot]]
[[File:The Haymarket Martyrs.jpg|thumb|The Haymarket Martyrs]]
;4 May 1886 (United States) :Anarchist rally lead to the [[Haymarket Riot]] in Chicago, [[Illinois]], the origin of international [[May Day]] observances.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;22 November 1887 (United States) :In the [[Thibodaux massacre]] in [[Thibodaux, Louisiana]] a local militia, aided by bands of "prominent citizens," shot at least 35 unarmed black sugar workers striking to gain a dollar-per-day wage, and lynched two strike leaders.
;1887 (United States) :Seven of the [[Haymarket Riot]] bombing defendants sentenced to death, of which five are executed.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1887 (United States) :[[Port of New York Longshoremen's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:Union Labor Campaign Poster 1888.jpg|thumb|alt=1888 Union Labor Poster |Union Labor Party campaign poster (1888)]]
;June 1888 (United Kingdom) :The [[London matchgirls strike of 1888]] was a [[Industrial action|strike]] of the women and [[teenage]] girls working at the [[Bryant and May Factory, Bow|Bryant and May Factory]] in [[Bow, London|Bow]], London. The strike was prompted by the poor working conditions in the [[match]] factory, including fourteen-hour work days, poor pay, excessive fines, and the severe health complications of working with yellow (or white) [[phosphorus]], such as [[phossy jaw]].
;1888 (United States) :United States enacted first federal labor relations law; the law applied only to railroads.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1888 (United States) :[[International Association of Machinists]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1888 (United States) :[[Burling Railroad Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1888 (United States) :[[Cincinnati Shoemakers' Lockout]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1889 (United States) :[[Baseball Players' Revolt]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1889 (United States) :[[Fall River, Massachusetts, Textile Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1889 (Europe) :The [[Second International]] is founded. Declaration of 1 May as [[International Workers Day]].
===1890s===
;1890 (United States) :[[United Mine Workers of America]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1890 (United States) :[[United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America]] Strike occurred; the union demanded an eight-hour work day.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
